countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail to log activities on EFS access points
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Elastic File System (EFS) provides file storage for your cloud applications and services. To ensure the security and integrity of your data, it is crucial to monitor changes and access patterns on EFS access points. Implementing AWS CloudTrail to log activities is a key step in achieving this.

Implementation Guidance for Cloud Engineers

  1. Enable AWS CloudTrail in your AWS account. CloudTrail provides event history of your AWS account activity, including actions on EFS access points.
  2. Configure CloudTrail to capture Data Events for EFS. This is essential as it enables logging of API activity for each file system.
  3. Create a new Trail if you do not already have one configured. Ensure that you specify the S3 bucket where log files will be stored and, if needed, enable logging to CloudWatch Logs for real-time monitoring.
  4. Customize your CloudTrail logs to monitor specific EFS access points, focusing on events such as the creation, deletion, or modification of access points. This can be achieved by using the AddDataFeature and specifying AccessPoint in your trail configurations.
  5. Regularly review the logs generated by CloudTrail to identify any unauthorized or suspicious activities. Utilize AWS CloudWatch Logs to set up metric filters and alarms for predefined criteria to automate this process.
  6. Ensure that all CloudTrail logs are encrypted using AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to protect sensitive information from being exposed.

For detailed instructions and best practices, refer to the official AWS documentation on security considerations for EFS: AWS EFS Security Considerations and on monitoring EFS access points: Amazon EFS Access Points Monitoring.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to define and attach policies that control access to EFS file systems via access points
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your AWS EFS (Elastic File System), it is essential to use AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to manage access control. This involves defining and attaching appropriate IAM policies that specify who can access your EFS file systems and through which access points. Below are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Navigate to the IAM console in the AWS Management Console.
  2. Create a new IAM policy that defines the allowed actions for EFS. Use the JSON editor to specify conditions based on user roles, IP addresses, or other criteria. For example:        {            "Version": "2012-10-17",            "Statement": [                {                    "Effect": "Allow",                    "Action": [                        "elasticfilesystem:ClientMount",                        "elasticfilesystem:ClientWrite"                    ],                    "Resource": "arn:aws:elasticfilesystem:region:account-id:file-system/efs-id",                    "Condition": {                        "StringEquals": {                            "aws:RequestTag/access-point": "access-point-id"                        }                    }                }            ]        }        
  3. Attach the IAM policy to the relevant IAM users, groups, or roles that require access to the EFS file system. Ensure that these entities have the necessary permissions to use the specified access points.
  4. Regularly review and update the IAM policies to ensure they align with the changing needs and security posture of your organization.

For more detailed security considerations, please refer to the AWS EFS Security Considerations documentation and the specific guidance provided for Amazon EFS Access Points Security.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized file system access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Ineffective identity and permission management mechanisms could potentially expose the file system to unauthorized access.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors, including external attackers, insiders, and compromised accounts, could exploit inadequacies in access control policies and identity management procedures to gain illegal access to the file system.
Impacts
Possible impacts may include data breaches, loss of sensitive information, legal penalties, and damage to the organizations reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
- An external attacker exploits weak identity management protocols to gain unauthorized access to the file system.
- A former employee retains access due to insufficient revocation of permissions after leaving the organization, potentially leading to data theft.
- An insider with more access than needed intentionally accesses sensitive data to sell it or use it for malicious purposes.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data leakage through mount targets
threat.desc:
General threat description
Exposed mount targets within an AWS EFS can result in significant data leakage and unauthorized access if not properly secured.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or unauthorized users exploiting improperly configured security groups, network ACLs, or IAM policies associated with EFS mount targets.
Impacts
Unauthorized data access, potential data corruption, data exfiltration, non-compliance with data protection regulations, and overall loss of data integrity and confidentiality.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers an EFS mount target with default security group settings allowing unrestricted access and proceeds to access and exfiltrate sensitive data. Alternatively, internal employees with inappropriate permissions might access confidential data they are not authorized to view or modify, leading to potential internal data breaches.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

threat.name: Inadequate encryption of data at rest
threat.desc:
General threat description
A lack of encryption for data stored in AWS EFS can result in data breaches when unauthorized parties obtain access to the storage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users, malicious insiders, or external attackers can access sensitive data stored in EFS if it is not properly encrypted. Attack vectors may include compromised user credentials, exploiting vulnerabilities, or man-in-the-middle attacks.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data can lead to data breaches, financial loss, reputational damage, legal consequences, and regulatory non-compliance.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker with access to compromised credentials of an AWS account can directly access unencrypted sensitive files stored on EFS. 2. A malicious insider copies unencrypted data from EFS and sells it to competitors or posts it publicly. 3. An attacker intercepts data in transit to or from an unencrypted EFS instance during a man-in-the-middle attack, gaining access to confidential information.

threat.name: Unauthorized public access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Public access to Amazon EFS can result in unauthorized users gaining entry to sensitive data or manipulating resources, posing a significant security risk.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors exploiting misconfigured EFS settings that allow public access or using compromised credentials to access the file system.
Impacts
Unauthorized data exposure, data theft, data corruption, and potential compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
A misconfigured EFS is accidentally left open to the public, allowing a hacker to access and exfiltrate sensitive data. Alternatively, an attacker using stolen credentials could manipulate the data stored in the EFS, resulting in data loss or corruption.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Compromised access points
threat.desc:
General threat description
If an access point is compromised, an attacker could use it to exfiltrate data or modify files in an unauthorized manner.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers could gain access through phishing attacks, exploiting vulnerabilities in applications that access AWS EFS, or by leveraging stolen credentials.
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized data disclosure, data corruption, financial loss, and potential legal repercussions.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access through a compromised access point and starts downloading sensitive business documents. Alternatively, the attacker could modify configuration files, disrupting business operations by altering crucial settings or injecting malicious code.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring of access points
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper monitoring, unauthorized actions on access points might go unnoticed, leading to potential data breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers, or compromised accounts can exploit the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions such as accessing, modifying, or deleting sensitive data.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, financial losses, legal consequences, and damage to the organizations reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An external attacker gains access to compromised credentials and modifies access point configurations to exfiltrate data. A malicious insider with legitimate access to an EFS access point deletes key files, causing operational disruptions and data loss.

countermeasure.name: Configure broker logs delivery to CloudWatch, S3, or Firehose
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security monitoring of your AWS Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka (MSK) cluster, configure your MSK cluster to deliver INFO-level broker logs to destinations such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs, Amazon S3, or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. Implementing this countermeasure involves the following steps:

  1. Enable Broker Logging: Ensure that broker logging is enabled on your MSK cluster. You can specify the log delivery options when you create the cluster or update the configuration of an existing cluster. Refer to the MSK logging documentation for detailed instructions.
  2. Choose Log Destination: Decide where you want the logs to be delivered:
    • Amazon CloudWatch Logs: Select this option for real-time monitoring and alerting capabilities. Configure the log group and define IAM roles and policies for log delivery. For more information, refer to CloudWatch Logs setup guide.
    • Amazon S3: Use S3 to store logs for long-term retention and analysis. Specify the S3 bucket and implement the required IAM policies. Refer to S3 logs setup guide.
    • Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose: Choose Firehose for streamlining log processing and delivery to various destinations. Set up the Firehose delivery stream and apply the necessary IAM policies. See the Firehose setup guide for further details.
  3. Secure IAM Roles and Policies: Ensure that the IAM roles and policies associated with log delivery have the least privilege necessary to perform their functions. Refer to the IAM Security guidelines in the MSK documentation for best practices.
  4. Verify Log Delivery: After configuring log delivery, validate that logs are being correctly sent to the chosen destination. Check the log streams in CloudWatch, the objects in your S3 bucket, or the records in Kinesis Firehose to ensure logs are comprehensive and correctly timestamped.
  5. Monitor and Analyze Logs: Regularly monitor and analyze the INFO-level broker logs to detect any unusual or unauthorized activities. Use AWS security tools like Amazon GuardDuty and AWS Security Hub for advanced threat detection and correlation of log data. Detailed steps can be found in the Monitoring Guide.

For comprehensive security guidelines, please refer to the AWS MSK Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Update security group rules to restrict access
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure that your clients have access to the brokers in your AWS MSK cluster, you need to properly configure the security group's rules associated with your MSK cluster. This involves setting inbound and outbound rules that allow traffic between your clients and the brokers while maintaining adherence to AWS security best practices. Below is a step-by-step guide:

  1. Identify the Security Group: First, identify the security group currently associated with your MSK cluster. You can find this information in the AWS Management Console by navigating to the Amazon MSK console.

  2. Access the Security Group Settings: In the MSK console, go to the Cluster details page and then to the Network section. Note the IDs of the security groups used by the brokers.

  3. Edit Inbound Rules: Navigate to the Amazon EC2 console, and then to the Security Groups section. Locate the security groups identified in the previous step, and edit their inbound rules to allow necessary traffic from your clients. Ensure you add rules for the appropriate ports used by MSK (default is TCP port 9092).

    • Click on the Inbound rules tab.
    • Click on the Edit inbound rules button.
    • Add a new rule to allow traffic from your client IP ranges. Specify the Protocol (TCP), Port Range (9092), and the appropriate Source (your clients IP or Security Group ID).
    • Click on the Save rules button to apply the changes.

  4. Edit Outbound Rules: Ensure the outbound rules permit traffic to the client IPs. Similar to inbound rules, edit the outbound rules for the security group to allow traffic to specified IP ranges and ports.

    • Click on the Outbound rules tab.
    • Click on the Edit outbound rules button.
    • Add a new rule to allow traffic to your client IP ranges. Specify the Protocol (TCP), Port Range (9092 or other custom ports), and the appropriate Destination (your clients IP or Security Group ID).
    • Click on the Save rules button to apply the changes.

  5. Verify the Configuration: After configuring the security group's rules, ensure that your clients can connect to the brokers without issues. Test the connectivity and ensure that the proper permissions are in place.

  6. Review and Maintain: Regularly review and update the security group rules to align with changing security requirements and best practices. Reference the AWS Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka security documentation for any updates or additional guidelines: AWS MSK Security Documentation.

Following these steps ensures that your AWS MSK cluster remains accessible to legitimate clients while adhering to security best practices as outlined in the AWS documentation. For more detailed guidelines, please refer to the AWS official documentation on changing security groups: Change Security Group for AWS MSK.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM to authenticate clients for Apache Kafka APIs
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon MSK allows you to leverage AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) to authenticate clients and control Apache Kafka actions. This enables secure and fine-grained access control mechanisms. To implement this, follow these guidelines:

  1. Set Up IAM Policies: Create IAM policies that specify the Kafka actions permitted for your users or applications. Refer to IAM Access Control for Amazon MSK for detailed instructions on crafting policies.
  2. Attach Policies to Users or Roles: Assign the newly created IAM policies to users or roles that need access to your MSK clusters. This can be done via the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.
  3. Configure Client Authentication: Update your Apache Kafka clients to use IAM for authentication. The AWS SDK provides mechanisms for this, including automatic signing of requests with IAM credentials. Details can be found in the section Client Authentication with IAM.
  4. Update Cluster Configurations: Modify the MSK cluster configurations to enable IAM authentication. This can be managed through the AWS Management Console or the AWS CLI. More information is available in the MSK Cluster Configuration documentation.
  5. Regularly Review and Audit IAM Policies: Review and audit your IAM policies and roles periodically to ensure that only the necessary permissions are granted. This ensures adherence to the principle of least privilege, reducing potential security vulnerabilities.

By following these steps and best practices, you can leverage IAM to securely authenticate clients and manage access to Kafka actions within your MSK clusters.

For further information on securing your Amazon MSK clusters, visit the Official Amazon MSK Security Documentation.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Incorrect security group settings
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured security group settings can expose your Managed Streaming for Apache Kafka cluster to unauthorized users.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Potential attackers can exploit insecure security group rules to access your MSK cluster. This could include open ports, overly permissive IP ranges, or missing firewall restrictions.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, data loss, unauthorized data manipulation, or disruption of the Kafka service. Sensitive information could be exposed, and overall system integrity could be compromised.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker scans a network and discovers an MSK cluster with open access to all IP addresses. The attacker then connects to the cluster, reads sensitive data, and performs unauthorized operations such as deleting topics or disrupting service availability.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Apache Kafka APIs
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized users could potentially exploit weak authentication mechanisms to access sensitive data and services within the AWS MSK environment.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious actors such as hackers or insiders who exploit weak passwords, misconfigured authentication settings, or vulnerabilities in the authentication protocol. Common attack vectors might involve brute force attacks, phishing schemes, or exploiting known vulnerabilities in authentication mechanisms.
Impacts
The unauthorized access can lead to data breaches, exposure of confidential information, service disruptions, or unauthorized manipulation of data streams. This could result in significant financial loss, reputation damage, and potential compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
For example, an attacker might use a brute force attack to guess weak passwords and log into an AWS MSK cluster. Once inside, they could access and exfiltrate sensitive data or disrupt service operations by altering data streams. Another scenario could involve a phishing attack where employees are tricked into disclosing their authentication credentials, which are then used by attackers to gain unauthorized access to the MSK environment.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of log management for broker activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate logging configurations can lead to challenges in identifying and addressing security incidents involving broker operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers, or automated threats that exploit the lack of proper logging to perform unauthorized activities without detection.
Impacts
Difficulty in forensic analysis, prolonged incident response times, potential data breaches, and compliance violations.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a broker and performs unauthorized actions such as extracting sensitive data or disrupting services. The lack of logs makes it challenging to detect the breach promptly and understand the extent of the malicious activities.

weakness.name: CWE-200

weakness.name: CWE-269

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Configure Amazon Cognito authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to your Amazon OpenSearch dashboards, you can authenticate users using Amazon Cognito. This method allows you to take advantage of Amazon Cognito's user pools and identity pools to manage and authenticate users. Below are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Create an Amazon Cognito User Pool: Start by setting up a User Pool in Amazon Cognito. User Pools are user directories that provide sign-up and sign-in options for your application users. For more details, refer to the AWS documentation on Amazon Cognito User Pools.

  2. Create an Amazon Cognito Identity Pool: Establish an Identity Pool that enables you to obtain temporary AWS credentials for your users, thus allowing them to access AWS resources. You can link this Identity Pool to your User Pool in order to authenticate users with their credentials. For a comprehensive guide, see Amazon Cognito Identity Pools.

  3. Configure OpenSearch Security Settings: Navigate to the OpenSearch Service console. Under the security settings for your OpenSearch domain, choose Amazon Cognito for the authentication system. Fill in the User Pool ID and Identity Pool ID that you created in the previous steps. You will also need to configure the App Client ID and callback URLs. Detailed instructions are available at Authenticating Dashboard Users with Amazon Cognito.

  4. Verify and Test: Ensure that the setup is correctly implemented by testing the login flow. Access the OpenSearch Dashboards and verify you can securely log in using an Amazon Cognito authenticated user account.

For further information and security best practices, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation available at AWS OpenSearch Service Security.

countermeasure.name: Configure JWT authentication and authorization
countermeasure.desc:
JSON Web Token (JWT) authentication and authorization provide secure token-based authentication for AWS OpenSearch. Implementing this countermeasure ensures that only authenticated and authorized users can access your OpenSearch domains, enhancing security by reducing unauthorized access risks.

To enable JWT authentication and authorization for AWS OpenSearch:

  1. Ensure that your OpenSearch domain is configured to use Fine-Grained Access Control (FGAC). FGAC provides the capability to define access policies based on users and roles.
  2. Generate JWTs through a trusted Identity Provider (IdP) such as Amazon Cognito, Auth0, or any other compliant IdP. The IdP should support OpenID Connect (OIDC) protocol for JWT issuance.
  3. Configure your OpenSearch domain to accept JWTs by setting up the appropriate issuer and audience fields. These fields will correspond to the IdPs metadata and ensure that OpenSearch validates the JWT correctly.
  4. Create fine-grained access control policies within OpenSearch to map users, roles, and permission sets based on attributes within the JWT. This mapping allows for precise access control over OpenSearch resources.
  5. Test JWT authentication by generating a JWT from your IdP and accessing your OpenSearch endpoint using this token. Verify that access is granted or denied according to the FGAC policies youve configured.

Detailed steps and code samples are available in the AWS OpenSearch Service documentation: JSON Web Tokens. Additionally, ensure you're familiar with AWS OpenSearch security best practices to safeguard your OpenSearch resources effectively.

countermeasure.name: Create an interface VPC endpoint
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Amazon OpenSearch Service domain, setting up a service-managed VPC endpoint is essential. This setup ensures that network traffic between your Amazon VPC and OpenSearch Service domain remains within the AWS network, significantly reducing exposure to potential threats and unauthorized access.

Follow these steps to configure an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint:

  1. Create a VPC: Ensure that you have a VPC in place to which you can attach the endpoint. If you don't have one, create a VPC using the Amazon VPC console or the AWS CLI. For more details, visit Creating a VPC.

  2. Create Subnets: Set up private subnets within the VPC if they don't already exist. OpenSearch Service-managed endpoints require subnets within your VPC. For more information, see the VPC Subnets documentation.

  3. Set up Security Groups: Configure security groups to control inbound and outbound traffic to and from the VPC endpoint. Security groups act as virtual firewalls, allowing you to specify traffic rules. Refer to the Security Groups documentation for detailed guidance.

  4. Configure VPC Endpoints: Navigate to the Amazon VPC console, select "Endpoints," and create a new endpoint. Choose the OpenSearch Service as the service name and attach it to your specific VPC and subnets. Reference the VPC Endpoints documentation for step-by-step instructions.

  5. Update OpenSearch Domain: Alter the network settings of your OpenSearch domain to associate it with the newly created VPC endpoint. This step ensures that traffic to your OpenSearch domain traverses the configured VPC endpoint. Specific instructions can be found under Managing VPC in OpenSearch.

  6. Test Endpoint Connectivity: Finally, validate the configuration by testing connectivity to your OpenSearch domain through the VPC endpoint. Make sure that all traffic routes securely and verify access restrictions.

Implementing an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint is crucial for enhancing security posture by securing network traffic and restricting unauthorized access. For further security best practices, consult the OpenSearch Service security documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your stored data in AWS OpenSearch, it is crucial to enable encryption of data at rest using AWS Key Management Service (KMS). This countermeasure helps prevent unauthorized access to your data and ensures compliance with security best practices.

Steps to Enable Encryption at Rest using AWS KMS:

  1. Navigate to the AWS Management Console.

  2. Open the AWS OpenSearch Service console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/opensearch.

  3. Select the OpenSearch domain where you want to enable encryption.

  4. In the 'Actions' dropdown menu, choose Edit security configuration.

  5. Scroll down to the Encryption at rest section.

  6. Check the box to enable encryption at rest.

  7. From the KMS master key dropdown, select an existing KMS key or create a new one. For more detailed guidance on creating and managing KMS keys, refer to the AWS KMS documentation.

  8. After selecting the KMS key, click Save changes to apply the configuration.

For further details on enabling encryption at rest with AWS OpenSearch, please refer to the official Encryption at rest documentation.

Additional information regarding AWS OpenSearch security practices can be found in the AWS OpenSearch Security Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
Enable Fine-Grained Access Control to Provide Security at the Index, Document, and Field Level

Fine-grained access control (FGAC) allows you to secure your AWS Opensearch Service domains more precisely by controlling access at the index, document, and field levels. This countermeasure ensures that only authorized users can access sensitive data, thereby enhancing the security posture of your OpenSearch environment.

To implement fine-grained access control, follow these steps:

Step 1: Enable Fine-Grained Access Control

When creating a new domain or modifying an existing domain, enable fine-grained access control. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the OpenSearch Service and click on your domain. Under the "Security configuration" section, enable the "Enable fine-grained access control" option.

Step 2: Configure Master User

Define a master user who has full access to the domain. The master user can then configure access control policies. In the "Fine-grained access control" settings, specify the master user ARN or username, which will be used for all initial domain configuration activities.

Step 3: Define Index Patterns and Roles

Create index patterns to define which indices the roles will have access to. Roles allow you to map permissions to users and groups while defining read, write, and manage access to specific indices. For each role, specify the index permissions and document-level security queries.

  1. Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  2. Create a new role and define the necessary privileges (e.g., read, write) for the specific index patterns.

Step 4: Assign Users to Roles

Assign users or groups to the roles you've created. This can be done through the AWS IAM integration or by using the internal user database within the OpenSearch Service.

Step 5: Configure Field-Level Security

Field-level security settings can further restrict access to specific fields within documents:

  • Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  • Edit the role to include field-level security settings, specifying which fields are to be hidden or included.

By following these steps, you can effectively use fine-grained access control in AWS OpenSearch, ensuring that users only access the data they are authorized to view or modify.

For further details and advanced configurations, refer to the official AWS OpenSearch Service documentation on fine-grained access control: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/fgac.html

For comprehensive security practices including encryption, network security, and audit logging, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/security.html

countermeasure.name: Enable SAML authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your OpenSearch Dashboards, it is recommended to configure SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication using existing identity providers (IdPs). This integration allows your users to log in to OpenSearch Dashboards using their corporate credentials, leveraging your organization's existing identity management system. The following steps guide the process of configuring SAML authentication:

  1. Setup Identity Provider (IdP):

    Ensure that your IdP supports SAML 2.0. Obtain the necessary metadata URL or file from your IdP that will be required during configuration. Common IdPs include Okta, OneLogin, and Microsoft Azure AD.

  2. Access OpenSearch Service Console:

    Navigate to the Amazon OpenSearch Service console. Select the domain where you want to configure SAML authentication and go to the "Security" section.
    Reference Link

  3. Configure SAML Authentication:

    In the SAML authentication section, provide the following details:

    • Metadata URL/File: Provide the metadata URL or upload the metadata file from your IdP.
    • Entity ID: This is a unique identifier for the SAML service provider. Ensure it matches the Entity ID in your IdP configuration.
    • Service Provider Endpoints: Configure endpoints such as Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL that AWS OpenSearch uses to receive SAML assertions from the IdP.
  4. Update Roles and Mappings:

    Define the mappings between SAML attributes and OpenSearch roles. This mapping allows users to inherit specific permissions based on their SAML assertions.
    Reference Link

  5. Testing and Validation:

    After you complete the configuration, perform a series of tests to ensure that the SAML authentication is working correctly. Have users attempt to log in using their corporate credentials to confirm successful integration.

For detailed instructions and additional configuration options, refer to the official AWS documentation:
AWS OpenSearch Service Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use aws SourceArn in policies
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the confused deputy problem and ensure that permissions are correctly scoped to specific resources, you should use the aws:SourceArn global condition context key in your IAM policies. This technique ensures that only requests originating from the specified Amazon Resource Name (ARN) can access your AWS OpenSearch Service resources.

Here is a step-by-step guide for implementing this control:

  1. Identify the ARNs of the services or resources that require access to your OpenSearch indices or clusters.
  2. Create or modify the appropriate IAM policy or resource policy to include the aws:SourceArn condition key. This key verifies that the call to access the OpenSearch resource is coming from the correct source.
  3. Ensure that the policy condition specifically restricts permissions to the identified ARNs.

Below is an example of an IAM policy that uses aws:SourceArn to limit access:


{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "es:ESHttpGet",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:es:region:account-id:domain/your-domain/*",
            "Condition": {
                "StringEquals": {
                    "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:lambda:region:account-id:function:your-lambda-function"
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}

In this example, the policy allows HTTP GET requests to an OpenSearch domain only if the request originates from a specified AWS Lambda function.

For further information on preventing the confused deputy problem and securing your OpenSearch Service resources, refer to the AWS official documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use service-linked roles
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the principle of least privilege while managing AWS OpenSearch Service, it is crucial to implement service-linked roles that delegate the minimal necessary permissions. This security practice helps to mitigate risks associated with overly broad permissions and enhances the overall security posture of your AWS environment.

Follow these steps to implement service-linked roles:

  1. Navigate to the IAM Roles console in AWS Management Console.
  2. Click on the "Create role" button.
  3. Choose "AWS Service" as the trusted entity and select "OpenSearch Service" from the list of services.
  4. Select the "OpenSearchService" use case to automatically attach required policies for the service-linked role.
  5. Review the permissions and ensure that they align with the principle of least privilege. Make modifications if necessary to tailor to your specific requirements.
  6. Provide a role name and optional description, then create the role.

After the role has been created, OpenSearch Service will automatically assume this role to perform actions on your behalf. This ensures that the permissions granted are limited to only what is necessary for OpenSearch Service to function effectively.

For comprehensive information on service-linked roles for OpenSearch, refer to the Service-linked roles documentation.

Additionally, consult the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation for more guidelines on securing your OpenSearch Service environment.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access control
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access controls failure can result in unauthorized users gaining access to system resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external attackers, rogue employees, and opportunistic insiders who exploit weak access control policies, misconfigured IAM roles, or exposed access credentials.
Impacts
This can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized modifications, and compromised system integrity, potentially resulting in financial losses and damage to organizational reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers an exposed AWS access key on a public code repository and uses it to gain access to OpenSearch, where they extract sensitive data. Additionally, a disgruntled employee who retains access after termination could potentially alter or delete critical data due to poor access revocation practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

threat.name: Weak IAM role permissions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate IAM role permissions can result in excessive privileges being exploited by malicious entities, enabling unauthorized access or modifications to AWS resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers leveraging insufficiently restrictive IAM roles to gain elevated privileges.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of services, data loss or corruption, and significant financial or reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an over-permissioned IAM role and uses it to access and exfiltrate sensitive data from an AWS Opensearch cluster, or a compromised account with excessive permissions is used to delete or alter critical infrastructure settings, causing service disruptions.

threat.name: Confused deputy problem
threat.desc:
General threat description
A security issue arises when an entity without direct permissions can manipulate a more-privileged entity into performing actions on its behalf. This can lead to unauthorized access or modification of data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers. They may exploit vulnerabilities in the permission settings or leverage social engineering techniques to coerce privileged entities.
Impacts
The impacts can range from unauthorized data access and data manipulation to privilege escalation and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could craft a malicious API request that appears legitimate, tricking a more-privileged service into executing it and accessing restricted data. Alternatively, a compromised low-privilege account could send commands that appear to come from a legitimate high-privilege service, leading to unauthorized data modifications.

threat.name: Single sign-on vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Configuring SSO without adequate security measures can expose the system to various security threats.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or automated scripts which can exploit vulnerabilities such as weak authentication protocols, inadequate encryption, or misconfigured access controls in the SSO implementation.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, service disruptions, and compromised user accounts, which can lead to significant financial losses and damage to an organizations reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may exploit a poorly configured SSO system by using phishing techniques to steal valid user credentials and gain access to multiple linked applications. In another scenario, a malicious insider might leverage inadequate access controls to elevate their privileges and perform unauthorized actions across the network.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to stored data, which can lead to data leakage or manipulation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised credentials, misconfigured access controls.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive or proprietary information, financial loss, regulatory fines, damage to reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS Opensearch cluster using stolen credentials and extracts sensitive business data. Alternatively, a misconfiguration in access controls allows an unauthorized user to manipulate stored data, leading to inaccurate business analytics and decision-making.

threat.name: Unregulated network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
When an AWS Opensearch instance is configured with direct and unfiltered network access, it can become susceptible to unauthorized access and potential security breaches. This misconfiguration could lead to exposure of sensitive data and undermine the integrity and availability of the Opensearch service.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors including cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or external adversaries could exploit unfiltered network access to gain unauthorized entry. They might use network scanning tools, automated scripts, or brute force attacks to identify and infiltrate the misconfigured Opensearch instance.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to an Opensearch instance can have several severe impacts, including data theft, data corruption, loss of sensitive information, disruption of services, financial losses due to mitigation and response efforts, and damage to an organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker scans the network for open and unfiltered access points, discovers the misconfigured Opensearch instance, and exfiltrates sensitive business data. 2. A malicious insider connects to the Opensearch instance via unfiltered network access, manipulates or deletes significant indexes, causing data integrity issues and operational disruptions. 3. An external hacker leverages automated tools to identify unprotected Opensearch instances and executes exploits to inject malicious data or ransomware, demanding a ransom for data restoration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Insufficient authentication management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper authentication management may lead to compromised security in OpenSearch Dashboards.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit weak or misconfigured authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access to OpenSearch Dashboards. This can occur through various methods such as brute force attacks, exploiting default credentials, or phishing.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in disclosure of sensitive information, data manipulation, unauthorized administrative actions, and overall loss of data integrity and confidentiality.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a brute force attack to guess weak administrator credentials and gains full access to OpenSearch Dashboards. Another scenario could involve an internal actor exploiting default credentials that were not changed after initial setup, leading to unauthorized access and potential data tampering.

threat.name: Unsecured authentication
threat.desc:
General threat description
The use of weak or inadequate authentication methods can lead to unauthorized access to AWS Opensearch clusters, exposing sensitive data and compromising system integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or script kiddies. Attack vectors often involve brute force attacks, phishing, or exploiting weak passwords and inadequate multi-factor authentication.
Impacts
Impacts include data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized data manipulation, service disruptions, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could launch a brute force attack against an Opensearch cluster's login interface, eventually gaining access due to weak passwords. Alternatively, an attacker could exploit a lack of multi-factor authentication to gain access through compromised credentials obtained via a phishing campaign.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

  5. Test JWT authentication by generating a JWT from your IdP and accessing your OpenSearch endpoint using this token. Verify that access is granted or denied according to the FGAC policies youve configured.

Detailed steps and code samples are available in the AWS OpenSearch Service documentation: JSON Web Tokens. Additionally, ensure you're familiar with AWS OpenSearch security best practices to safeguard your OpenSearch resources effectively.

countermeasure.name: Create an interface VPC endpoint
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Amazon OpenSearch Service domain, setting up a service-managed VPC endpoint is essential. This setup ensures that network traffic between your Amazon VPC and OpenSearch Service domain remains within the AWS network, significantly reducing exposure to potential threats and unauthorized access.

Follow these steps to configure an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint:

  1. Create a VPC: Ensure that you have a VPC in place to which you can attach the endpoint. If you don't have one, create a VPC using the Amazon VPC console or the AWS CLI. For more details, visit Creating a VPC.

  2. Create Subnets: Set up private subnets within the VPC if they don't already exist. OpenSearch Service-managed endpoints require subnets within your VPC. For more information, see the VPC Subnets documentation.

  3. Set up Security Groups: Configure security groups to control inbound and outbound traffic to and from the VPC endpoint. Security groups act as virtual firewalls, allowing you to specify traffic rules. Refer to the Security Groups documentation for detailed guidance.

  4. Configure VPC Endpoints: Navigate to the Amazon VPC console, select "Endpoints," and create a new endpoint. Choose the OpenSearch Service as the service name and attach it to your specific VPC and subnets. Reference the VPC Endpoints documentation for step-by-step instructions.

  5. Update OpenSearch Domain: Alter the network settings of your OpenSearch domain to associate it with the newly created VPC endpoint. This step ensures that traffic to your OpenSearch domain traverses the configured VPC endpoint. Specific instructions can be found under Managing VPC in OpenSearch.

  6. Test Endpoint Connectivity: Finally, validate the configuration by testing connectivity to your OpenSearch domain through the VPC endpoint. Make sure that all traffic routes securely and verify access restrictions.

Implementing an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint is crucial for enhancing security posture by securing network traffic and restricting unauthorized access. For further security best practices, consult the OpenSearch Service security documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your stored data in AWS OpenSearch, it is crucial to enable encryption of data at rest using AWS Key Management Service (KMS). This countermeasure helps prevent unauthorized access to your data and ensures compliance with security best practices.

Steps to Enable Encryption at Rest using AWS KMS:

  1. Navigate to the AWS Management Console.

  2. Open the AWS OpenSearch Service console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/opensearch.

  3. Select the OpenSearch domain where you want to enable encryption.

  4. In the 'Actions' dropdown menu, choose Edit security configuration.

  5. Scroll down to the Encryption at rest section.

  6. Check the box to enable encryption at rest.

  7. From the KMS master key dropdown, select an existing KMS key or create a new one. For more detailed guidance on creating and managing KMS keys, refer to the AWS KMS documentation.

  8. After selecting the KMS key, click Save changes to apply the configuration.

For further details on enabling encryption at rest with AWS OpenSearch, please refer to the official Encryption at rest documentation.

Additional information regarding AWS OpenSearch security practices can be found in the AWS OpenSearch Security Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
Enable Fine-Grained Access Control to Provide Security at the Index, Document, and Field Level

Fine-grained access control (FGAC) allows you to secure your AWS Opensearch Service domains more precisely by controlling access at the index, document, and field levels. This countermeasure ensures that only authorized users can access sensitive data, thereby enhancing the security posture of your OpenSearch environment.

To implement fine-grained access control, follow these steps:

Step 1: Enable Fine-Grained Access Control

When creating a new domain or modifying an existing domain, enable fine-grained access control. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the OpenSearch Service and click on your domain. Under the "Security configuration" section, enable the "Enable fine-grained access control" option.

Step 2: Configure Master User

Define a master user who has full access to the domain. The master user can then configure access control policies. In the "Fine-grained access control" settings, specify the master user ARN or username, which will be used for all initial domain configuration activities.

Step 3: Define Index Patterns and Roles

Create index patterns to define which indices the roles will have access to. Roles allow you to map permissions to users and groups while defining read, write, and manage access to specific indices. For each role, specify the index permissions and document-level security queries.

  1. Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  2. Create a new role and define the necessary privileges (e.g., read, write) for the specific index patterns.

Step 4: Assign Users to Roles

Assign users or groups to the roles you've created. This can be done through the AWS IAM integration or by using the internal user database within the OpenSearch Service.

Step 5: Configure Field-Level Security

Field-level security settings can further restrict access to specific fields within documents:

  • Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  • Edit the role to include field-level security settings, specifying which fields are to be hidden or included.

By following these steps, you can effectively use fine-grained access control in AWS OpenSearch, ensuring that users only access the data they are authorized to view or modify.

For further details and advanced configurations, refer to the official AWS OpenSearch Service documentation on fine-grained access control: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/fgac.html

For comprehensive security practices including encryption, network security, and audit logging, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/security.html

countermeasure.name: Enable SAML authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your OpenSearch Dashboards, it is recommended to configure SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication using existing identity providers (IdPs). This integration allows your users to log in to OpenSearch Dashboards using their corporate credentials, leveraging your organization's existing identity management system. The following steps guide the process of configuring SAML authentication:

  1. Setup Identity Provider (IdP):

    Ensure that your IdP supports SAML 2.0. Obtain the necessary metadata URL or file from your IdP that will be required during configuration. Common IdPs include Okta, OneLogin, and Microsoft Azure AD.

  2. Access OpenSearch Service Console:

    Navigate to the Amazon OpenSearch Service console. Select the domain where you want to configure SAML authentication and go to the "Security" section.
    Reference Link

  3. Configure SAML Authentication:

    In the SAML authentication section, provide the following details:

    • Metadata URL/File: Provide the metadata URL or upload the metadata file from your IdP.
    • Entity ID: This is a unique identifier for the SAML service provider. Ensure it matches the Entity ID in your IdP configuration.
    • Service Provider Endpoints: Configure endpoints such as Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL that AWS OpenSearch uses to receive SAML assertions from the IdP.
  4. Update Roles and Mappings:

    Define the mappings between SAML attributes and OpenSearch roles. This mapping allows users to inherit specific permissions based on their SAML assertions.
    Reference Link

  5. Testing and Validation:

    After you complete the configuration, perform a series of tests to ensure that the SAML authentication is working correctly. Have users attempt to log in using their corporate credentials to confirm successful integration.

For detailed instructions and additional configuration options, refer to the official AWS documentation:
AWS OpenSearch Service Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use aws SourceArn in policies
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the confused deputy problem and ensure that permissions are correctly scoped to specific resources, you should use the aws:SourceArn global condition context key in your IAM policies. This technique ensures that only requests originating from the specified Amazon Resource Name (ARN) can access your AWS OpenSearch Service resources.

Here is a step-by-step guide for implementing this control:

  1. Identify the ARNs of the services or resources that require access to your OpenSearch indices or clusters.
  2. Create or modify the appropriate IAM policy or resource policy to include the aws:SourceArn condition key. This key verifies that the call to access the OpenSearch resource is coming from the correct source.
  3. Ensure that the policy condition specifically restricts permissions to the identified ARNs.

Below is an example of an IAM policy that uses aws:SourceArn to limit access:


{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "es:ESHttpGet",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:es:region:account-id:domain/your-domain/*",
            "Condition": {
                "StringEquals": {
                    "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:lambda:region:account-id:function:your-lambda-function"
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}

In this example, the policy allows HTTP GET requests to an OpenSearch domain only if the request originates from a specified AWS Lambda function.

For further information on preventing the confused deputy problem and securing your OpenSearch Service resources, refer to the AWS official documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use service-linked roles
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the principle of least privilege while managing AWS OpenSearch Service, it is crucial to implement service-linked roles that delegate the minimal necessary permissions. This security practice helps to mitigate risks associated with overly broad permissions and enhances the overall security posture of your AWS environment.

Follow these steps to implement service-linked roles:

  1. Navigate to the IAM Roles console in AWS Management Console.
  2. Click on the "Create role" button.
  3. Choose "AWS Service" as the trusted entity and select "OpenSearch Service" from the list of services.
  4. Select the "OpenSearchService" use case to automatically attach required policies for the service-linked role.
  5. Review the permissions and ensure that they align with the principle of least privilege. Make modifications if necessary to tailor to your specific requirements.
  6. Provide a role name and optional description, then create the role.

After the role has been created, OpenSearch Service will automatically assume this role to perform actions on your behalf. This ensures that the permissions granted are limited to only what is necessary for OpenSearch Service to function effectively.

For comprehensive information on service-linked roles for OpenSearch, refer to the Service-linked roles documentation.

Additionally, consult the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation for more guidelines on securing your OpenSearch Service environment.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Confused deputy problem
threat.desc:
General threat description
A security issue arises when an entity without direct permissions can manipulate a more-privileged entity into performing actions on its behalf. This can lead to unauthorized access or modification of data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers. They may exploit vulnerabilities in the permission settings or leverage social engineering techniques to coerce privileged entities.
Impacts
The impacts can range from unauthorized data access and data manipulation to privilege escalation and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could craft a malicious API request that appears legitimate, tricking a more-privileged service into executing it and accessing restricted data. Alternatively, a compromised low-privilege account could send commands that appear to come from a legitimate high-privilege service, leading to unauthorized data modifications.

threat.name: Single sign-on vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Configuring SSO without adequate security measures can expose the system to various security threats.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or automated scripts which can exploit vulnerabilities such as weak authentication protocols, inadequate encryption, or misconfigured access controls in the SSO implementation.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, service disruptions, and compromised user accounts, which can lead to significant financial losses and damage to an organizations reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may exploit a poorly configured SSO system by using phishing techniques to steal valid user credentials and gain access to multiple linked applications. In another scenario, a malicious insider might leverage inadequate access controls to elevate their privileges and perform unauthorized actions across the network.

threat.name: Inadequate access control
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access controls failure can result in unauthorized users gaining access to system resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external attackers, rogue employees, and opportunistic insiders who exploit weak access control policies, misconfigured IAM roles, or exposed access credentials.
Impacts
This can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized modifications, and compromised system integrity, potentially resulting in financial losses and damage to organizational reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers an exposed AWS access key on a public code repository and uses it to gain access to OpenSearch, where they extract sensitive data. Additionally, a disgruntled employee who retains access after termination could potentially alter or delete critical data due to poor access revocation practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

threat.name: Weak IAM role permissions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate IAM role permissions can result in excessive privileges being exploited by malicious entities, enabling unauthorized access or modifications to AWS resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers leveraging insufficiently restrictive IAM roles to gain elevated privileges.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of services, data loss or corruption, and significant financial or reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an over-permissioned IAM role and uses it to access and exfiltrate sensitive data from an AWS Opensearch cluster, or a compromised account with excessive permissions is used to delete or alter critical infrastructure settings, causing service disruptions.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to stored data, which can lead to data leakage or manipulation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised credentials, misconfigured access controls.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive or proprietary information, financial loss, regulatory fines, damage to reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS Opensearch cluster using stolen credentials and extracts sensitive business data. Alternatively, a misconfiguration in access controls allows an unauthorized user to manipulate stored data, leading to inaccurate business analytics and decision-making.

threat.name: Unregulated network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
When an AWS Opensearch instance is configured with direct and unfiltered network access, it can become susceptible to unauthorized access and potential security breaches. This misconfiguration could lead to exposure of sensitive data and undermine the integrity and availability of the Opensearch service.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors including cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or external adversaries could exploit unfiltered network access to gain unauthorized entry. They might use network scanning tools, automated scripts, or brute force attacks to identify and infiltrate the misconfigured Opensearch instance.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to an Opensearch instance can have several severe impacts, including data theft, data corruption, loss of sensitive information, disruption of services, financial losses due to mitigation and response efforts, and damage to an organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker scans the network for open and unfiltered access points, discovers the misconfigured Opensearch instance, and exfiltrates sensitive business data. 2. A malicious insider connects to the Opensearch instance via unfiltered network access, manipulates or deletes significant indexes, causing data integrity issues and operational disruptions. 3. An external hacker leverages automated tools to identify unprotected Opensearch instances and executes exploits to inject malicious data or ransomware, demanding a ransom for data restoration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Insufficient authentication management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper authentication management may lead to compromised security in OpenSearch Dashboards.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit weak or misconfigured authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access to OpenSearch Dashboards. This can occur through various methods such as brute force attacks, exploiting default credentials, or phishing.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in disclosure of sensitive information, data manipulation, unauthorized administrative actions, and overall loss of data integrity and confidentiality.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a brute force attack to guess weak administrator credentials and gains full access to OpenSearch Dashboards. Another scenario could involve an internal actor exploiting default credentials that were not changed after initial setup, leading to unauthorized access and potential data tampering.

threat.name: Unsecured authentication
threat.desc:
General threat description
The use of weak or inadequate authentication methods can lead to unauthorized access to AWS Opensearch clusters, exposing sensitive data and compromising system integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or script kiddies. Attack vectors often involve brute force attacks, phishing, or exploiting weak passwords and inadequate multi-factor authentication.
Impacts
Impacts include data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized data manipulation, service disruptions, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could launch a brute force attack against an Opensearch cluster's login interface, eventually gaining access due to weak passwords. Alternatively, an attacker could exploit a lack of multi-factor authentication to gain access through compromised credentials obtained via a phishing campaign.

component.name: Amazon S3
component.desc: Amazon S3 bucket storing the source cluster snapshot.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Object Lock
countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.
