usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: DDoS attack on ELB
threat.desc:
General threat description: A Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack involves overwhelming the ELB with a flood of requests, causing service disruption and potentially leading to downtime for the web application.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include botnets and malicious actors leveraging a large number of compromised systems to generate excessive traffic.

Impacts: Impacts include reduced availability of the web application, potential loss of revenue, and degraded user experience.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker uses a botnet to send a massive volume of traffic to the ELB, overwhelming its capacity and causing legitimate requests to fail.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Misconfigured security groups
threat.desc:
General threat description: Misconfigured security groups associated with the ELB can expose backend instances to unauthorized access, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized actions.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include attackers scanning for open ports and services exposed due to overly permissive security group settings.

Impacts: Impacts include unauthorized access to backend systems, data breaches, and potential control over application components.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker finds an open port on a backend instance due to a misconfigured security group, gaining unauthorized access to sensitive data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data in transit
threat.desc:
General threat description: Data transmitted between clients and the ELB or between the ELB and backend instances that is not encrypted can be intercepted and read by unauthorized parties, leading to information disclosure.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include attackers on the same network or those who have compromised intermediary communication channels.

Impacts: Impacts include the exposure of sensitive information such as user credentials, personal data, and application-specific information.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic between a client and the ELB, capturing login credentials and session information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description: Insufficient logging and monitoring of the ELB can lead to a lack of visibility into malicious activities, making it difficult to detect, investigate, and respond to security incidents.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include malicious insiders and external attackers exploiting the lack of visibility to carry out their activities undetected.

Impacts: Impacts include undetected data breaches, delayed incident response, and difficulty in forensic analysis.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker exploits a vulnerability in the web application served by the ELB, but due to insufficient logging, the activity goes unnoticed for an extended period.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Man-in-the-middle attack on ELB traffic
threat.desc:
General threat description: A man-in-the-middle (MitM) attack occurs when an attacker intercepts communication between the ELB and the client or between the ELB and backend servers. This can lead to unauthorized access to sensitive information or the ability to manipulate traffic.

Threat agents/Attack vectors: Threat agents include malicious actors on the network who can intercept and manipulate traffic. Common attack vectors involve network vulnerabilities or compromised intermediate systems.

Impacts: The primary impacts include loss of confidentiality and integrity of data, leading to potential data breaches and tampered communications.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  • An attacker gains access to a network segment and intercepts traffic between the client and ELB, capturing sensitive data or injecting malicious payloads.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt sensitive data within event payloads
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard sensitive data contained within event payloads and protect against unauthorized access by interceptors, it is crucial to implement encryption. This process should involve selecting a robust encryption algorithm, such as AES (Advanced Encryption Standard), to ensure data confidentiality during transit. Begin by identifying which data within the event payloads is considered sensitive, and tailor the encryption strategy accordingly.

First, integrate an encryption library that supports your chosen algorithm into the event-streaming application. Ensure that this library is compatible with the development environment and has been vetted for security vulnerabilities and compliance with relevant security standards.

Next, implement encryption functions within the event-processing codebase. Whenever an event is generated or processed, these functions should encrypt the designated sensitive fields within the payload before the event is published to the event stream. Be sure to handle encryption keys securely by utilizing a key management service (KMS) for storing, retrieving, and rotating keys, thereby minimizing the risk of key exposure.

When decrypting event payloads, ensure that the logic only permits authorized consumers to access the decrypted data. Implement strict access controls and authentication mechanisms to verify consumer permissions prior to decryption.

Finally, conduct thorough testing to verify that encryption and decryption mechanisms do not adversely impact system performance or functionality. This includes testing under various load conditions and ensuring that encrypted data is correctly transmitted and received across different components of the event-streaming platform.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement fine-grained access controls
countermeasure.desc:
To safeguard the event streaming platform from unauthorized access and control, establishing detailed access control policies and roles is essential. This involves a structured approach to permissions management, ensuring that access rights are granted based on user roles and responsibilities.

  • Role Definition: Begin by clearly defining roles within your organization. Identify various job functions and the level of access each requires within the event streaming platform. Common roles might include viewer, contributor, and administrator.
  • Policy Creation: Develop comprehensive access control policies. Document the access levels for each role, specifying which resources and operations are accessible. Ensure that policies align with organizational security requirements and compliance standards.
  • Access Control Tools: Utilize the platforms built-in access control tools or integrate external Identity and Access Management (IAM) solutions to enforce policies. These tools help in managing user identities and assigning roles conveniently.
  • Least Privilege Principle: Implement the principle of least privilege. Users should be granted the minimum level of access necessary to perform their job functions. Regularly review and adjust permissions to reflect any changes in job responsibilities.
  • User Authentication: Enforce strong authentication mechanisms, such as Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA), to secure user accounts. This adds an extra layer of protection, ensuring that even if credentials are compromised, unauthorized access is still prevented.
  • Automated Monitoring and Auditing: Deploy automated monitoring systems to track access and usage patterns. Regularly audit access logs to identify and respond to unauthorized access attempts promptly.
  • Continuous Training: Educate employees on the importance of access control policies and the security risks associated with unauthorized access. Regular training sessions should be conducted to keep staff aware of best practices and any changes in policies.
  • Regular Policy Review: Schedule regular reviews of access control policies to ensure they remain effective and up-to-date with organizational changes or threat landscape shifts. Amend policies as required to address new challenges or vulnerabilities.

By implementing these measures, organizations can effectively limit unauthorized control and access to the event streaming platform, thus ensuring data integrity and security.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

countermeasure.name: Restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the event streaming platform, it is crucial to limit network access, thereby reducing potential attack vectors and preventing unauthorized access. Implement the following guidelines to effectively apply this countermeasure:

  • Network Segmentation:

    Divide the enterprise network into distinct segments to isolate the event streaming platform from other business-critical systems. This involves configuring network boundaries, employing firewalls, and establishing clear demarcation lines to minimize lateral movement in case of a breach.

  • Access Control Lists (ACLs):

    Utilize ACLs to define and enforce specific rules regarding which IP addresses or network ranges can access the event streaming platform. Ensure the lists are continuously reviewed and updated to reflect changes in the network, and restrict access to only necessary systems and users.

  • VPN and Secure Connections:

    Implement Virtual Private Network (VPN) tunnels to secure remote access to the platform. Ensure that all data transmission is encrypted and authenticated using strong cryptographic protocols, such as TLS or IPsec, to safeguard against interception and data tampering.

  • Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

    Employ RBAC to ensure users have minimum necessary permissions to fulfill their roles. Regularly audit user roles and permissions to maintain alignment with changing responsibilities and enforce the principle of least privilege.

  • Continuous Monitoring and Logging:

    Implement continuous network monitoring and logging to detect unauthorized access attempts and anomalies. Utilize intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS), and establish alerting mechanisms to notify security teams of suspicious activities in real-time.

  • Regular Security Testing:

    Conduct penetration testing and vulnerability assessments periodically to identify and remediate security weaknesses. This proactive approach ensures that network access restrictions are effective against evolving threats.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to control environment
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to the control mechanisms of the event streaming platform poses a significant risk as it can lead to service disruptions or data exfiltration.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors posing as legitimate users or exploiting vulnerabilities in the system's authentication or access control mechanisms.
Impacts
Potential impacts include service outages, unauthorized data access or theft, and loss of customer trust or revenue.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker might use stolen credentials to impersonate a user with admin privileges, or exploit a zero-day vulnerability to bypass access controls, leading to unauthorized platform changes or data theft.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Man in the middle attack
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers could intercept communications between components of the event streaming platform, allowing them to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data transmitted across the network.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals or malicious insiders could use techniques like packet sniffing or DNS spoofing to carry out these attacks while communications are in transit.
Impacts
Compromised data integrity and confidentiality, financial loss, and damage to the organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker sets up a rogue networking device on the same network as the event streaming platform, intercepts sensitive data such as API keys or user credentials, and uses this information to access internal systems or sell it on the dark web.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Exploitation of wide attack surface
threat.desc:
General threat description
Attackers take advantage of the extensive attack surface area of the event streaming platform to identify and exploit vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Potential threat actors include external attackers or malicious insiders who have varying degrees of access to the platform. They may employ techniques such as scanning for open ports, injecting malicious code, or leveraging unpatched software vulnerabilities.
Impacts
Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could lead to unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of data streaming, compromise of system integrity, and potential financial loss due to service downtime or data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could scan the platform's network to find exposed services, then leverage a known vulnerability in one of the services to gain unauthorized access. Alternatively, a malicious insider might use their access rights to insert harmful payloads into the data stream, causing data corruption or loss.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-539
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-539: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information. Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. This lets the application use the cookie to pass information between pages and store variable information. The web application controls what information is stored in a cookie and how it is used. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers, personalization and customization information, and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere, but persistent cookies are stored on the browser's hard drive. This can cause security and privacy issues depending on the information stored in the cookie and how it is accessed.

weakness.name: CWE-922
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-922: Insecure Storage of Sensitive Information The product stores sensitive information without properly limiting read or write access by unauthorized actors. If read access is not properly restricted, then attackers can steal the sensitive information. If write access is not properly restricted, then attackers can modify and possibly delete the data, causing incorrect results and possibly a denial of service.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption for data in transit during migration
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that all data transferred during migration processes is encrypted using Transport Layer Security (TLS) to protect it from interception. Implement encryption at all points of the migration process, from the source to the destination. Regularly audit network traffic to verify that encryption is being properly enforced and that no sensitive information is being transmitted in cleartext.

Implement alerts for any suspicious or unauthorized data manipulations.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Data loss due to migration failure or interruption
threat.desc:
General threat description: 

Migration processes can fail or be interrupted due to network issues, misconfigurations, or system crashes. This can result in partial or complete data loss, leading to significant disruptions in business operations. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors: 

Network disruptions, human error during configuration, or unexpected system failures. 

Impacts: 

Loss of critical business data, extended downtime, and difficulty in restoring normal operations. Example Attack Scenarios: 

A migration process is interrupted due to a network outage, leading to incomplete data transfer and potential data loss.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data leakage due to unencrypted data transfer
threat.desc:
General threat description: 

If data transferred during migration is not encrypted, it may be vulnerable to unauthorized access, particularly if intercepted during transit. This can result in sensitive data exposure and potential data breaches. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors: 

Attackers performing man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, compromised network infrastructure, or insiders intercepting unencrypted data transfers. 

Impacts: 

Unauthorized disclosure of sensitive data, potential data breaches, legal and regulatory consequences, and damage to organizational reputation. 

Example Attack Scenarios: 

An attacker intercepts unencrypted data being transferred during a migration process, leading to the exposure of sensitive customer information.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to migration data
threat.desc:
General threat description: 

During the migration process, data is transferred from the source environment to Alibaba Cloud. Unauthorized access to this data can occur due to weak authentication mechanisms, misconfigurations, or exploitation of vulnerabilities in the migration tool, leading to potential data breaches. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors: 

External attackers exploiting weak authentication, insiders with excessive privileges, or automated tools designed to intercept migration data. 

Impacts: 

Data breaches, unauthorized data modification, loss of service availability, and potential legal and regulatory penalties. 

Example Attack Scenarios: 

An attacker gains unauthorized access to the migration tool using compromised credentials, allowing them to intercept and exfiltrate sensitive data during the migration process.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insider threat leading to unauthorized data manipulation during migration
threat.desc:
General threat description: 

Insiders with access to the migration tool may misuse their privileges to manipulate or delete data during the migration process, leading to data integrity issues, financial losses, or operational disruptions. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors: 

Disgruntled employees, contractors with access to the migration tool, or third-party service providers with privileged access. 

Impacts: 

Unauthorized data modification, data loss, corruption of critical records, and potential compliance violations. 

Example Attack Scenarios: 

A system administrator with access to the migration tool intentionally alters critical data during the migration process, causing significant disruption to business operations.

threat.name: Misconfiguration leading to incomplete or failed migrations
threat.desc:
General threat description: 

Misconfigurations in the migration tool or incorrect settings during the migration process can lead to incomplete data transfer, data corruption, or failed migrations, causing disruptions in business operations. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors: 

Human error, lack of proper validation, or inadequate testing of migration configurations. 

Impacts: 

Loss of data integrity, incomplete migration, service downtime, and potential business disruptions. 

Example Attack Scenarios: 

A misconfigured migration process fails to transfer all necessary data, resulting in an incomplete migration and operational issues in the target environment.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Safeguard your root user credentials and use them to perform the tasks that only the root user can perform
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security posture of your AWS Migration Hub environment, it is critical to restrict the use of the AWS account root user for everyday tasks and reserve it only for actions that require root user credentials. Implementing this countermeasure minimizes the risk of root account compromise, which can have severe repercussions for your cloud infrastructure.

Steps to Implement:

  1. Create IAM Users: Establish AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) users with the necessary permissions for daily operational tasks. Each user should have a unique set of credentials to enforce accountability and facilitate monitoring. Refer to the AWS guidelines on creating IAM users for more information.
  2. Assign Permissions via IAM Policies: Define and attach granular IAM policies to the user roles to grant the minimum required permissions. For AWS Migration Hub activities, align permissions according to AWS best practices covered in the AWS Migration Hub security documentation.
  3. Enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Protect the root user and all IAM users with Multi-Factor Authentication to add an extra layer of security. Detailed steps to enable MFA can be found in the AWS MFA documentation.
  4. Monitor Root Account Activity: Regularly review the usage of your AWS root account. Utilize AWS CloudTrail to track and log all root user actions, ensuring any unusual or unauthorized activities are promptly detected. Refer to the official AWS CloudTrail documentation for configuration and usage guidelines.
  5. Secure Root Account Credentials: Ensure that the root users credentials are stored securely and are not used for daily operations. These credentials should only be accessed when absolutely necessary and should be managed as described in the AWS IAM best practices.

By following these steps and adhering to AWSs security documentation, you can effectively limit the use of the root account and significantly reduce the potential impact of a compromised root account on your AWS Migration Hub environment.

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection

countermeasure.name: Use CloudTrail to log, continuously monitor, and retain account activity
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure all activities related to AWS Migration Hub are logged, enabling transparency, troubleshooting, and facilitating audits, you must configure AWS CloudTrail to capture all relevant events. This approach aligns with best practices outlined in the AWS Migration Hub logging and monitoring documentation.

Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Enable CloudTrail: Ensure that AWS CloudTrail is enabled in all regions where you are using AWS Migration Hub. This can be done via the AWS Management Console, AWS CLI, or AWS SDKs.
    • In the AWS Management Console, navigate to CloudTrail and choose Create trail.
    • Ensure the trail applies to All regions to capture all activities across different regional endpoints.
  2. Configure Event Selectors: Define event selectors to include management events which capture operations performed on AWS Migration Hub. Ensure these event selectors are set to log both Read and Write management events.
    • Under the trail settings, navigate to Event selectors and ensure both Read and Write events are selected for management events.
  3. Store and Monitor Logs: Set the S3 bucket to store CloudTrail logs, ensuring appropriate access policies are in place to safeguard the logs. Utilize AWS CloudWatch Logs for real-time monitoring and alerts.
    • In the CloudTrail configuration, specify an S3 bucket for log storage and configure appropriate bucket policies to control access.
    • Enable integration with CloudWatch Logs for continuous tracking and set up alarms for critical events.
  4. Review and Audit Logs Regularly: Regularly review CloudTrail logs to identify any suspicious activities or anomalies. Utilize AWS Athena for querying logs for comprehensive audits.
    • Periodically analyze the logs using CloudTrail Insights and AWS Athena for deep inspection of activities related to AWS Migration Hub.

For more detailed information on securing AWS Migration Hub, please refer to the official security guide at AWS Migration Hub Security.

standard.ref: PR.PT-1: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to AWS Migration Hub resources
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to AWS Migration Hub resources can lead to the compromise of sensitive data or disruption of operations.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious actors or unauthorized users leveraging weak authentication, poor access control policies, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the system.
Impacts
Data breaches, operational downtime, financial loss, and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses stolen credentials to access AWS Migration Hub, extracting sensitive data and altering migration operations, leading to significant business disruption and financial loss.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of transparency in AWS Migration Hub account activity
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper logging and monitoring, malicious activities or unauthorized accesses may go undetected in AWS Migration Hub.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents could include external attackers, malicious insiders, or automated bots. Attack vectors may involve leveraging undetected vulnerabilities, exploiting weak access controls, or performing unauthorized actions without being noticed.
Impacts
The impacts can include unauthorized data access, data breaches, loss of sensitive information, compliance violations, and financial losses. Additionally, the lack of visibility into activities can hinder forensic investigations and delay incident response.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An external attacker exploits an unpatched vulnerability and gains unauthorized access to sensitive data in the AWS Migration Hub without triggering any alerts.
2. A malicious insider accesses and exfiltrates confidential migration data, knowing that the activities are not being logged or monitored, thus avoiding detection.
3. Automated bots conduct a series of unauthorized operations in the AWS Migration Hub, and the absence of monitoring means these actions remain unnoticed until significant damage is done.

component.desc: Infrastructure used for migrating the OpenSearch/Elasticsearch cluster.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Configure Amazon Cognito authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to your Amazon OpenSearch dashboards, you can authenticate users using Amazon Cognito. This method allows you to take advantage of Amazon Cognito's user pools and identity pools to manage and authenticate users. Below are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Create an Amazon Cognito User Pool: Start by setting up a User Pool in Amazon Cognito. User Pools are user directories that provide sign-up and sign-in options for your application users. For more details, refer to the AWS documentation on Amazon Cognito User Pools.

  2. Create an Amazon Cognito Identity Pool: Establish an Identity Pool that enables you to obtain temporary AWS credentials for your users, thus allowing them to access AWS resources. You can link this Identity Pool to your User Pool in order to authenticate users with their credentials. For a comprehensive guide, see Amazon Cognito Identity Pools.

  3. Configure OpenSearch Security Settings: Navigate to the OpenSearch Service console. Under the security settings for your OpenSearch domain, choose Amazon Cognito for the authentication system. Fill in the User Pool ID and Identity Pool ID that you created in the previous steps. You will also need to configure the App Client ID and callback URLs. Detailed instructions are available at Authenticating Dashboard Users with Amazon Cognito.

  4. Verify and Test: Ensure that the setup is correctly implemented by testing the login flow. Access the OpenSearch Dashboards and verify you can securely log in using an Amazon Cognito authenticated user account.

For further information and security best practices, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation available at AWS OpenSearch Service Security.

countermeasure.name: Configure JWT authentication and authorization
countermeasure.desc:
JSON Web Token (JWT) authentication and authorization provide secure token-based authentication for AWS OpenSearch. Implementing this countermeasure ensures that only authenticated and authorized users can access your OpenSearch domains, enhancing security by reducing unauthorized access risks.

To enable JWT authentication and authorization for AWS OpenSearch:

  1. Ensure that your OpenSearch domain is configured to use Fine-Grained Access Control (FGAC). FGAC provides the capability to define access policies based on users and roles.
  2. Generate JWTs through a trusted Identity Provider (IdP) such as Amazon Cognito, Auth0, or any other compliant IdP. The IdP should support OpenID Connect (OIDC) protocol for JWT issuance.
  3. Configure your OpenSearch domain to accept JWTs by setting up the appropriate issuer and audience fields. These fields will correspond to the IdPs metadata and ensure that OpenSearch validates the JWT correctly.
  4. Create fine-grained access control policies within OpenSearch to map users, roles, and permission sets based on attributes within the JWT. This mapping allows for precise access control over OpenSearch resources.
  5. Test JWT authentication by generating a JWT from your IdP and accessing your OpenSearch endpoint using this token. Verify that access is granted or denied according to the FGAC policies youve configured.

Detailed steps and code samples are available in the AWS OpenSearch Service documentation: JSON Web Tokens. Additionally, ensure you're familiar with AWS OpenSearch security best practices to safeguard your OpenSearch resources effectively.

countermeasure.name: Create an interface VPC endpoint
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Amazon OpenSearch Service domain, setting up a service-managed VPC endpoint is essential. This setup ensures that network traffic between your Amazon VPC and OpenSearch Service domain remains within the AWS network, significantly reducing exposure to potential threats and unauthorized access.

Follow these steps to configure an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint:

  1. Create a VPC: Ensure that you have a VPC in place to which you can attach the endpoint. If you don't have one, create a VPC using the Amazon VPC console or the AWS CLI. For more details, visit Creating a VPC.

  2. Create Subnets: Set up private subnets within the VPC if they don't already exist. OpenSearch Service-managed endpoints require subnets within your VPC. For more information, see the VPC Subnets documentation.

  3. Set up Security Groups: Configure security groups to control inbound and outbound traffic to and from the VPC endpoint. Security groups act as virtual firewalls, allowing you to specify traffic rules. Refer to the Security Groups documentation for detailed guidance.

  4. Configure VPC Endpoints: Navigate to the Amazon VPC console, select "Endpoints," and create a new endpoint. Choose the OpenSearch Service as the service name and attach it to your specific VPC and subnets. Reference the VPC Endpoints documentation for step-by-step instructions.

  5. Update OpenSearch Domain: Alter the network settings of your OpenSearch domain to associate it with the newly created VPC endpoint. This step ensures that traffic to your OpenSearch domain traverses the configured VPC endpoint. Specific instructions can be found under Managing VPC in OpenSearch.

  6. Test Endpoint Connectivity: Finally, validate the configuration by testing connectivity to your OpenSearch domain through the VPC endpoint. Make sure that all traffic routes securely and verify access restrictions.

Implementing an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint is crucial for enhancing security posture by securing network traffic and restricting unauthorized access. For further security best practices, consult the OpenSearch Service security documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your stored data in AWS OpenSearch, it is crucial to enable encryption of data at rest using AWS Key Management Service (KMS). This countermeasure helps prevent unauthorized access to your data and ensures compliance with security best practices.

Steps to Enable Encryption at Rest using AWS KMS:

  1. Navigate to the AWS Management Console.

  2. Open the AWS OpenSearch Service console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/opensearch.

  3. Select the OpenSearch domain where you want to enable encryption.

  4. In the 'Actions' dropdown menu, choose Edit security configuration.

  5. Scroll down to the Encryption at rest section.

  6. Check the box to enable encryption at rest.

  7. From the KMS master key dropdown, select an existing KMS key or create a new one. For more detailed guidance on creating and managing KMS keys, refer to the AWS KMS documentation.

  8. After selecting the KMS key, click Save changes to apply the configuration.

For further details on enabling encryption at rest with AWS OpenSearch, please refer to the official Encryption at rest documentation.

Additional information regarding AWS OpenSearch security practices can be found in the AWS OpenSearch Security Guide.

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Enable fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
Enable Fine-Grained Access Control to Provide Security at the Index, Document, and Field Level

Fine-grained access control (FGAC) allows you to secure your AWS Opensearch Service domains more precisely by controlling access at the index, document, and field levels. This countermeasure ensures that only authorized users can access sensitive data, thereby enhancing the security posture of your OpenSearch environment.

To implement fine-grained access control, follow these steps:

Step 1: Enable Fine-Grained Access Control

When creating a new domain or modifying an existing domain, enable fine-grained access control. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the OpenSearch Service and click on your domain. Under the "Security configuration" section, enable the "Enable fine-grained access control" option.

Step 2: Configure Master User

Define a master user who has full access to the domain. The master user can then configure access control policies. In the "Fine-grained access control" settings, specify the master user ARN or username, which will be used for all initial domain configuration activities.

Step 3: Define Index Patterns and Roles

Create index patterns to define which indices the roles will have access to. Roles allow you to map permissions to users and groups while defining read, write, and manage access to specific indices. For each role, specify the index permissions and document-level security queries.

  1. Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  2. Create a new role and define the necessary privileges (e.g., read, write) for the specific index patterns.

Step 4: Assign Users to Roles

Assign users or groups to the roles you've created. This can be done through the AWS IAM integration or by using the internal user database within the OpenSearch Service.

Step 5: Configure Field-Level Security

Field-level security settings can further restrict access to specific fields within documents:

  • Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  • Edit the role to include field-level security settings, specifying which fields are to be hidden or included.

By following these steps, you can effectively use fine-grained access control in AWS OpenSearch, ensuring that users only access the data they are authorized to view or modify.

For further details and advanced configurations, refer to the official AWS OpenSearch Service documentation on fine-grained access control: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/fgac.html

For comprehensive security practices including encryption, network security, and audit logging, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/security.html

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Enable SAML authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your OpenSearch Dashboards, it is recommended to configure SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication using existing identity providers (IdPs). This integration allows your users to log in to OpenSearch Dashboards using their corporate credentials, leveraging your organization's existing identity management system. The following steps guide the process of configuring SAML authentication:

  1. Setup Identity Provider (IdP):

    Ensure that your IdP supports SAML 2.0. Obtain the necessary metadata URL or file from your IdP that will be required during configuration. Common IdPs include Okta, OneLogin, and Microsoft Azure AD.

  2. Access OpenSearch Service Console:

    Navigate to the Amazon OpenSearch Service console. Select the domain where you want to configure SAML authentication and go to the "Security" section.
    Reference Link

  3. Configure SAML Authentication:

    In the SAML authentication section, provide the following details:

    • Metadata URL/File: Provide the metadata URL or upload the metadata file from your IdP.
    • Entity ID: This is a unique identifier for the SAML service provider. Ensure it matches the Entity ID in your IdP configuration.
    • Service Provider Endpoints: Configure endpoints such as Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL that AWS OpenSearch uses to receive SAML assertions from the IdP.
  4. Update Roles and Mappings:

    Define the mappings between SAML attributes and OpenSearch roles. This mapping allows users to inherit specific permissions based on their SAML assertions.
    Reference Link

  5. Testing and Validation:

    After you complete the configuration, perform a series of tests to ensure that the SAML authentication is working correctly. Have users attempt to log in using their corporate credentials to confirm successful integration.

For detailed instructions and additional configuration options, refer to the official AWS documentation:
AWS OpenSearch Service Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use aws SourceArn in policies
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the confused deputy problem and ensure that permissions are correctly scoped to specific resources, you should use the aws:SourceArn global condition context key in your IAM policies. This technique ensures that only requests originating from the specified Amazon Resource Name (ARN) can access your AWS OpenSearch Service resources.

Here is a step-by-step guide for implementing this control:

  1. Identify the ARNs of the services or resources that require access to your OpenSearch indices or clusters.
  2. Create or modify the appropriate IAM policy or resource policy to include the aws:SourceArn condition key. This key verifies that the call to access the OpenSearch resource is coming from the correct source.
  3. Ensure that the policy condition specifically restricts permissions to the identified ARNs.

Below is an example of an IAM policy that uses aws:SourceArn to limit access:


{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "es:ESHttpGet",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:es:region:account-id:domain/your-domain/*",
            "Condition": {
                "StringEquals": {
                    "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:lambda:region:account-id:function:your-lambda-function"
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}

In this example, the policy allows HTTP GET requests to an OpenSearch domain only if the request originates from a specified AWS Lambda function.

For further information on preventing the confused deputy problem and securing your OpenSearch Service resources, refer to the AWS official documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use service-linked roles
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the principle of least privilege while managing AWS OpenSearch Service, it is crucial to implement service-linked roles that delegate the minimal necessary permissions. This security practice helps to mitigate risks associated with overly broad permissions and enhances the overall security posture of your AWS environment.

Follow these steps to implement service-linked roles:

  1. Navigate to the IAM Roles console in AWS Management Console.
  2. Click on the "Create role" button.
  3. Choose "AWS Service" as the trusted entity and select "OpenSearch Service" from the list of services.
  4. Select the "OpenSearchService" use case to automatically attach required policies for the service-linked role.
  5. Review the permissions and ensure that they align with the principle of least privilege. Make modifications if necessary to tailor to your specific requirements.
  6. Provide a role name and optional description, then create the role.

After the role has been created, OpenSearch Service will automatically assume this role to perform actions on your behalf. This ensures that the permissions granted are limited to only what is necessary for OpenSearch Service to function effectively.

For comprehensive information on service-linked roles for OpenSearch, refer to the Service-linked roles documentation.

Additionally, consult the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation for more guidelines on securing your OpenSearch Service environment.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access control
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper access controls failure can result in unauthorized users gaining access to system resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include external attackers, rogue employees, and opportunistic insiders who exploit weak access control policies, misconfigured IAM roles, or exposed access credentials.
Impacts
This can lead to data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized modifications, and compromised system integrity, potentially resulting in financial losses and damage to organizational reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker discovers an exposed AWS access key on a public code repository and uses it to gain access to OpenSearch, where they extract sensitive data. Additionally, a disgruntled employee who retains access after termination could potentially alter or delete critical data due to poor access revocation practices.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1222 - File and Directory Permissions Modification

threat.name: Weak IAM role permissions
threat.desc:
General threat description
Inadequate IAM role permissions can result in excessive privileges being exploited by malicious entities, enabling unauthorized access or modifications to AWS resources.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents can include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers leveraging insufficiently restrictive IAM roles to gain elevated privileges.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, disruption of services, data loss or corruption, and significant financial or reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to an over-permissioned IAM role and uses it to access and exfiltrate sensitive data from an AWS Opensearch cluster, or a compromised account with excessive permissions is used to delete or alter critical infrastructure settings, causing service disruptions.

threat.name: Confused deputy problem
threat.desc:
General threat description
A security issue arises when an entity without direct permissions can manipulate a more-privileged entity into performing actions on its behalf. This can lead to unauthorized access or modification of data.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, compromised accounts, or external attackers. They may exploit vulnerabilities in the permission settings or leverage social engineering techniques to coerce privileged entities.
Impacts
The impacts can range from unauthorized data access and data manipulation to privilege escalation and potential data breaches.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could craft a malicious API request that appears legitimate, tricking a more-privileged service into executing it and accessing restricted data. Alternatively, a compromised low-privilege account could send commands that appear to come from a legitimate high-privilege service, leading to unauthorized data modifications.

threat.name: Single sign-on vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Configuring SSO without adequate security measures can expose the system to various security threats.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or automated scripts which can exploit vulnerabilities such as weak authentication protocols, inadequate encryption, or misconfigured access controls in the SSO implementation.
Impacts
Potential impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, service disruptions, and compromised user accounts, which can lead to significant financial losses and damage to an organizations reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker may exploit a poorly configured SSO system by using phishing techniques to steal valid user credentials and gain access to multiple linked applications. In another scenario, a malicious insider might leverage inadequate access controls to elevate their privileges and perform unauthorized actions across the network.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to stored data, which can lead to data leakage or manipulation.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised credentials, misconfigured access controls.
Impacts
Loss of sensitive or proprietary information, financial loss, regulatory fines, damage to reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to the AWS Opensearch cluster using stolen credentials and extracts sensitive business data. Alternatively, a misconfiguration in access controls allows an unauthorized user to manipulate stored data, leading to inaccurate business analytics and decision-making.

threat.name: Unregulated network access
threat.desc:
General threat description
When an AWS Opensearch instance is configured with direct and unfiltered network access, it can become susceptible to unauthorized access and potential security breaches. This misconfiguration could lead to exposure of sensitive data and undermine the integrity and availability of the Opensearch service.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors including cybercriminals, malicious insiders, or external adversaries could exploit unfiltered network access to gain unauthorized entry. They might use network scanning tools, automated scripts, or brute force attacks to identify and infiltrate the misconfigured Opensearch instance.
Impacts
Unauthorized access to an Opensearch instance can have several severe impacts, including data theft, data corruption, loss of sensitive information, disruption of services, financial losses due to mitigation and response efforts, and damage to an organization's reputation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker scans the network for open and unfiltered access points, discovers the misconfigured Opensearch instance, and exfiltrates sensitive business data. 2. A malicious insider connects to the Opensearch instance via unfiltered network access, manipulates or deletes significant indexes, causing data integrity issues and operational disruptions. 3. An external hacker leverages automated tools to identify unprotected Opensearch instances and executes exploits to inject malicious data or ransomware, demanding a ransom for data restoration.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Insufficient authentication management
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improper authentication management may lead to compromised security in OpenSearch Dashboards.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit weak or misconfigured authentication mechanisms to gain unauthorized access to OpenSearch Dashboards. This can occur through various methods such as brute force attacks, exploiting default credentials, or phishing.
Impacts
Unauthorized access can result in disclosure of sensitive information, data manipulation, unauthorized administrative actions, and overall loss of data integrity and confidentiality.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker uses a brute force attack to guess weak administrator credentials and gains full access to OpenSearch Dashboards. Another scenario could involve an internal actor exploiting default credentials that were not changed after initial setup, leading to unauthorized access and potential data tampering.

threat.name: Unsecured authentication
threat.desc:
General threat description
The use of weak or inadequate authentication methods can lead to unauthorized access to AWS Opensearch clusters, exposing sensitive data and compromising system integrity.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include malicious insiders, external attackers, or script kiddies. Attack vectors often involve brute force attacks, phishing, or exploiting weak passwords and inadequate multi-factor authentication.
Impacts
Impacts include data breaches, loss of sensitive information, unauthorized data manipulation, service disruptions, and potential legal consequences.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could launch a brute force attack against an Opensearch cluster's login interface, eventually gaining access due to weak passwords. Alternatively, an attacker could exploit a lack of multi-factor authentication to gain access through compromised credentials obtained via a phishing campaign.

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-306
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function The product does not perform any authentication for functionality that requires a provable user identity or consumes a significant amount of resources.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt data in transit and at rest
countermeasure.desc: Implement encryption protocols to secure data in transit and at rest, ensuring that sensitive information remains confidential even in the event of unauthorized access.

reference.name: OWASP Data Protection Guide

countermeasure.name: Configure Amazon Cognito authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to your Amazon OpenSearch dashboards, you can authenticate users using Amazon Cognito. This method allows you to take advantage of Amazon Cognito's user pools and identity pools to manage and authenticate users. Below are the steps to implement this countermeasure:

  1. Create an Amazon Cognito User Pool: Start by setting up a User Pool in Amazon Cognito. User Pools are user directories that provide sign-up and sign-in options for your application users. For more details, refer to the AWS documentation on Amazon Cognito User Pools.

  2. Create an Amazon Cognito Identity Pool: Establish an Identity Pool that enables you to obtain temporary AWS credentials for your users, thus allowing them to access AWS resources. You can link this Identity Pool to your User Pool in order to authenticate users with their credentials. For a comprehensive guide, see Amazon Cognito Identity Pools.

  3. Configure OpenSearch Security Settings: Navigate to the OpenSearch Service console. Under the security settings for your OpenSearch domain, choose Amazon Cognito for the authentication system. Fill in the User Pool ID and Identity Pool ID that you created in the previous steps. You will also need to configure the App Client ID and callback URLs. Detailed instructions are available at Authenticating Dashboard Users with Amazon Cognito.

  4. Verify and Test: Ensure that the setup is correctly implemented by testing the login flow. Access the OpenSearch Dashboards and verify you can securely log in using an Amazon Cognito authenticated user account.

For further information and security best practices, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation available at AWS OpenSearch Service Security.

countermeasure.name: Configure JWT authentication and authorization
countermeasure.desc:
JSON Web Token (JWT) authentication and authorization provide secure token-based authentication for AWS OpenSearch. Implementing this countermeasure ensures that only authenticated and authorized users can access your OpenSearch domains, enhancing security by reducing unauthorized access risks.

To enable JWT authentication and authorization for AWS OpenSearch:

  1. Ensure that your OpenSearch domain is configured to use Fine-Grained Access Control (FGAC). FGAC provides the capability to define access policies based on users and roles.
  2. Generate JWTs through a trusted Identity Provider (IdP) such as Amazon Cognito, Auth0, or any other compliant IdP. The IdP should support OpenID Connect (OIDC) protocol for JWT issuance.
  3. Configure your OpenSearch domain to accept JWTs by setting up the appropriate issuer and audience fields. These fields will correspond to the IdPs metadata and ensure that OpenSearch validates the JWT correctly.
  4. Create fine-grained access control policies within OpenSearch to map users, roles, and permission sets based on attributes within the JWT. This mapping allows for precise access control over OpenSearch resources.
  5. Test JWT authentication by generating a JWT from your IdP and accessing your OpenSearch endpoint using this token. Verify that access is granted or denied according to the FGAC policies youve configured.

Detailed steps and code samples are available in the AWS OpenSearch Service documentation: JSON Web Tokens. Additionally, ensure you're familiar with AWS OpenSearch security best practices to safeguard your OpenSearch resources effectively.

countermeasure.name: Create an interface VPC endpoint
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your Amazon OpenSearch Service domain, setting up a service-managed VPC endpoint is essential. This setup ensures that network traffic between your Amazon VPC and OpenSearch Service domain remains within the AWS network, significantly reducing exposure to potential threats and unauthorized access.

Follow these steps to configure an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint:

  1. Create a VPC: Ensure that you have a VPC in place to which you can attach the endpoint. If you don't have one, create a VPC using the Amazon VPC console or the AWS CLI. For more details, visit Creating a VPC.

  2. Create Subnets: Set up private subnets within the VPC if they don't already exist. OpenSearch Service-managed endpoints require subnets within your VPC. For more information, see the VPC Subnets documentation.

  3. Set up Security Groups: Configure security groups to control inbound and outbound traffic to and from the VPC endpoint. Security groups act as virtual firewalls, allowing you to specify traffic rules. Refer to the Security Groups documentation for detailed guidance.

  4. Configure VPC Endpoints: Navigate to the Amazon VPC console, select "Endpoints," and create a new endpoint. Choose the OpenSearch Service as the service name and attach it to your specific VPC and subnets. Reference the VPC Endpoints documentation for step-by-step instructions.

  5. Update OpenSearch Domain: Alter the network settings of your OpenSearch domain to associate it with the newly created VPC endpoint. This step ensures that traffic to your OpenSearch domain traverses the configured VPC endpoint. Specific instructions can be found under Managing VPC in OpenSearch.

  6. Test Endpoint Connectivity: Finally, validate the configuration by testing connectivity to your OpenSearch domain through the VPC endpoint. Make sure that all traffic routes securely and verify access restrictions.

Implementing an OpenSearch Service-managed VPC endpoint is crucial for enhancing security posture by securing network traffic and restricting unauthorized access. For further security best practices, consult the OpenSearch Service security documentation.

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the security of your stored data in AWS OpenSearch, it is crucial to enable encryption of data at rest using AWS Key Management Service (KMS). This countermeasure helps prevent unauthorized access to your data and ensures compliance with security best practices.

Steps to Enable Encryption at Rest using AWS KMS:

  1. Navigate to the AWS Management Console.

  2. Open the AWS OpenSearch Service console at https://console.aws.amazon.com/opensearch.

  3. Select the OpenSearch domain where you want to enable encryption.

  4. In the 'Actions' dropdown menu, choose Edit security configuration.

  5. Scroll down to the Encryption at rest section.

  6. Check the box to enable encryption at rest.

  7. From the KMS master key dropdown, select an existing KMS key or create a new one. For more detailed guidance on creating and managing KMS keys, refer to the AWS KMS documentation.

  8. After selecting the KMS key, click Save changes to apply the configuration.

For further details on enabling encryption at rest with AWS OpenSearch, please refer to the official Encryption at rest documentation.

Additional information regarding AWS OpenSearch security practices can be found in the AWS OpenSearch Security Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable fine-grained access control
countermeasure.desc:
Enable Fine-Grained Access Control to Provide Security at the Index, Document, and Field Level

Fine-grained access control (FGAC) allows you to secure your AWS Opensearch Service domains more precisely by controlling access at the index, document, and field levels. This countermeasure ensures that only authorized users can access sensitive data, thereby enhancing the security posture of your OpenSearch environment.

To implement fine-grained access control, follow these steps:

Step 1: Enable Fine-Grained Access Control

When creating a new domain or modifying an existing domain, enable fine-grained access control. In the AWS Management Console, navigate to the OpenSearch Service and click on your domain. Under the "Security configuration" section, enable the "Enable fine-grained access control" option.

Step 2: Configure Master User

Define a master user who has full access to the domain. The master user can then configure access control policies. In the "Fine-grained access control" settings, specify the master user ARN or username, which will be used for all initial domain configuration activities.

Step 3: Define Index Patterns and Roles

Create index patterns to define which indices the roles will have access to. Roles allow you to map permissions to users and groups while defining read, write, and manage access to specific indices. For each role, specify the index permissions and document-level security queries.

  1. Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  2. Create a new role and define the necessary privileges (e.g., read, write) for the specific index patterns.

Step 4: Assign Users to Roles

Assign users or groups to the roles you've created. This can be done through the AWS IAM integration or by using the internal user database within the OpenSearch Service.

Step 5: Configure Field-Level Security

Field-level security settings can further restrict access to specific fields within documents:

  • Navigate to "Security" > "Roles" in Kibana.
  • Edit the role to include field-level security settings, specifying which fields are to be hidden or included.

By following these steps, you can effectively use fine-grained access control in AWS OpenSearch, ensuring that users only access the data they are authorized to view or modify.

For further details and advanced configurations, refer to the official AWS OpenSearch Service documentation on fine-grained access control: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/fgac.html

For comprehensive security practices including encryption, network security, and audit logging, refer to the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/opensearch-service/latest/developerguide/security.html

countermeasure.name: Enable SAML authentication for OpenSearch Dashboards
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of your OpenSearch Dashboards, it is recommended to configure SAML (Security Assertion Markup Language) authentication using existing identity providers (IdPs). This integration allows your users to log in to OpenSearch Dashboards using their corporate credentials, leveraging your organization's existing identity management system. The following steps guide the process of configuring SAML authentication:

  1. Setup Identity Provider (IdP):

    Ensure that your IdP supports SAML 2.0. Obtain the necessary metadata URL or file from your IdP that will be required during configuration. Common IdPs include Okta, OneLogin, and Microsoft Azure AD.

  2. Access OpenSearch Service Console:

    Navigate to the Amazon OpenSearch Service console. Select the domain where you want to configure SAML authentication and go to the "Security" section.
    Reference Link

  3. Configure SAML Authentication:

    In the SAML authentication section, provide the following details:

    • Metadata URL/File: Provide the metadata URL or upload the metadata file from your IdP.
    • Entity ID: This is a unique identifier for the SAML service provider. Ensure it matches the Entity ID in your IdP configuration.
    • Service Provider Endpoints: Configure endpoints such as Assertion Consumer Service (ACS) URL that AWS OpenSearch uses to receive SAML assertions from the IdP.
  4. Update Roles and Mappings:

    Define the mappings between SAML attributes and OpenSearch roles. This mapping allows users to inherit specific permissions based on their SAML assertions.
    Reference Link

  5. Testing and Validation:

    After you complete the configuration, perform a series of tests to ensure that the SAML authentication is working correctly. Have users attempt to log in using their corporate credentials to confirm successful integration.

For detailed instructions and additional configuration options, refer to the official AWS documentation:
AWS OpenSearch Service Security Documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use aws SourceArn in policies
countermeasure.desc:
To mitigate the confused deputy problem and ensure that permissions are correctly scoped to specific resources, you should use the aws:SourceArn global condition context key in your IAM policies. This technique ensures that only requests originating from the specified Amazon Resource Name (ARN) can access your AWS OpenSearch Service resources.

Here is a step-by-step guide for implementing this control:

  1. Identify the ARNs of the services or resources that require access to your OpenSearch indices or clusters.
  2. Create or modify the appropriate IAM policy or resource policy to include the aws:SourceArn condition key. This key verifies that the call to access the OpenSearch resource is coming from the correct source.
  3. Ensure that the policy condition specifically restricts permissions to the identified ARNs.

Below is an example of an IAM policy that uses aws:SourceArn to limit access:


{
    "Version": "2012-10-17",
    "Statement": [
        {
            "Effect": "Allow",
            "Action": "es:ESHttpGet",
            "Resource": "arn:aws:es:region:account-id:domain/your-domain/*",
            "Condition": {
                "StringEquals": {
                    "aws:SourceArn": "arn:aws:lambda:region:account-id:function:your-lambda-function"
                }
            }
        }
    ]
}

In this example, the policy allows HTTP GET requests to an OpenSearch domain only if the request originates from a specified AWS Lambda function.

For further information on preventing the confused deputy problem and securing your OpenSearch Service resources, refer to the AWS official documentation.

countermeasure.name: Use service-linked roles
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure the principle of least privilege while managing AWS OpenSearch Service, it is crucial to implement service-linked roles that delegate the minimal necessary permissions. This security practice helps to mitigate risks associated with overly broad permissions and enhances the overall security posture of your AWS environment.

Follow these steps to implement service-linked roles:

  1. Navigate to the IAM Roles console in AWS Management Console.
  2. Click on the "Create role" button.
  3. Choose "AWS Service" as the trusted entity and select "OpenSearch Service" from the list of services.
  4. Select the "OpenSearchService" use case to automatically attach required policies for the service-linked role.
  5. Review the permissions and ensure that they align with the principle of least privilege. Make modifications if necessary to tailor to your specific requirements.
  6. Provide a role name and optional description, then create the role.

After the role has been created, OpenSearch Service will automatically assume this role to perform actions on your behalf. This ensures that the permissions granted are limited to only what is necessary for OpenSearch Service to function effectively.

For comprehensive information on service-linked roles for OpenSearch, refer to the Service-linked roles documentation.

Additionally, consult the AWS OpenSearch Service security documentation for more guidelines on securing your OpenSearch Service environment.
