usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion leading to denial of service
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Resource exhaustion in an ECS cluster occurs when CPU, memory, or network capacity is consumed by benign spikes or malicious workloads, preventing legitimate tasks from running and causing service outages.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious containers, compromised tasks, rogue admins or CI/CD pipelines.
  • Vectors:
    • Deploying tasks with unbounded resource requests (e.g. high CPU/memory).
    • Flooding the cluster with excessive task launch requests.
    • Memory leaks or runaway processes within containers.

Impacts

  • Task Failures: New and running services crash or are throttled.
  • Service Unavailability: APIs, jobs, and background processors become unresponsive.
  • Escalating Costs: Over-provisioned autoscaling spins up extra instances with no real demand.
  • Operational Overhead: Manual intervention needed to drain or rebalance the cluster.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Malicious Task Flood: An attacker with deploy rights launches hundreds of high-memory tasks, filling all container instances and blocking legitimate services.
  2. Runaway Process: A buggy microservice enters a tight loop consuming 100% CPU on its host; autoscaling cant keep up, and subsequent tasks remain pending.
  3. CI/CD Storm: A misconfigured pipeline repeatedly redeploys containers without resource limits, triggering rapid scale-outs and eventual cluster exhaustion.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Task execution role with excessive IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When an ECS task execution role is granted broad or wildcard IAM privileges, tasks gain more AWS access than requiredviolating least-privilege principles and enabling misuse.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious container code, compromised tasks, or insider threats.
  • Vectors:
    • Task roles with policies like iam:* or * on all resources.
    • Sharing execution roles across multiple services.
    • Inadequate policy scoping in Terraform/CloudFormation.

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Tasks can call sensitive APIscreating or deleting IAM users, roles, or keys.
  • Data Breach & Tampering: Unauthorized read/write of S3 buckets, secrets, or databases.
  • Lateral Movement: Pivoting to other AWS services or regions.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended resource creation or deletion.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A container uses its over-permissive role to call iam:CreateUser and issues new admin credentials.
  2. A compromised task reads secretsmanager:GetSecretValue, harvesting database passwords.
  3. A CI/CD pipeline with a wildcard execution role deploys tasks that spin up costly EC2 instances.

threat.name: Compromised container abusing AWS APIs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A breached container with AWS credentials (via task roles or env vars) can call AWS APIs to manipulate resources and move laterally in your account.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Supply-chain compromises, insiders, or remote code exploits
  • Vectors: Stealing IAM role tokens from the metadata endpoint, extracting hard-coded keys, abusing over-permissive task-role policies

Impacts

  • Privilege escalation and lateral movement
  • Data exfiltration from S3, RDS, etc.
  • Resource destruction or unauthorized creation
  • Persistent backdoors via new IAM principals

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Exploited app vulnerability reads task metadata, grabs role credentials, and deletes CloudFormation stacks.
  2. Malicious image embeds AWS keys, used to spin up costly EC2 instances.
  3. Over-privileged role abused to create an admin IAM user for ongoing access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Network exposure of container instances
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Network exposure of container instances occurs when ECS tasks or underlying EC2 instances are placed in subnets or security groups that allow unintended inbound or outbound trafficmaking them directly reachable from the Internet or other untrusted networks.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, opportunistic scanners, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Assigning container instances to public subnets without NAT or firewall controls.
    • Security groups permitting broad CIDRs (e.g. 0.0.0.0/0) on management ports (SSH, RDP) or application ports.
    • Misconfigured load-balancer target groups forwarding traffic to private instances.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can probe and exploit services running in containers.
  • Data Breach & Tampering: Exposed management interfaces allow configuration changes or credential theft.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious traffic or exploits lead to container crashes and downtime.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances become beachheads for attacking other resources in the VPC.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open SSH Port: A container instances SG allows SSH from anywhere; an attacker brute-forces the host and moves laterally into other ECS services.
  2. Public App Endpoint: A web service is deployed in a public subnet without WAF protection; vulnerability scanners find and exploit a known flaw, injecting malicious code.
  3. Load-Balancer Misroute: An internal-only API is mistakenly registered with a public ALB; its endpoints become reachable and are used to exfiltrate sensitive data.

threat.name: Lack of visibility into cluster and task activity
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without centralized logging or monitoring of ECS clusters and tasks, malicious or misconfigured activitysuch as unauthorized deployments, resource abuse, or lateral movementoccurs undetected.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised task containers, misconfigured CI/CD pipelines
  • Vectors:
    • No CloudWatch Logs or Container Insights enabled for task logs and metrics
    • Absence of CloudTrail events for RunTask, StopTask, or RegisterTaskDefinition
    • Missing EventBridge rules to capture ECS state changes

Impacts

  • Undetected Compromise: Rogue containers or altered task definitions run unnoticed
  • Delayed Response: Security incidents arent flagged, extending attacker dwell time
  • Compliance Gaps: Failure to meet audit-logging requirements (e.g., PCI DSS, SOC 2)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A rogue image is deployed via an unchecked pipeline; without audit logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A compromised task spins up crypto-mining containers; absent metrics alerts, resource exhaustion goes unremedied.
  3. An attacker uses the ECS API to stop security-critical tasks; no EventBridge rule exists to notify on task shutdown.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1613 - Container and Resource Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: DNS spoofing in service discovery
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
DNS spoofing in service discovery occurs when an attacker injects false DNS entrieseither via compromised DNS servers, poisoned caches, or manipulated /etc/hostscausing ECS tasks to resolve service names (e.g. your internal API or database endpoint) to malicious addresses.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised DNS resolvers, or on-host attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Poisoning the VPCs DNS resolver cache (e.g. via SSRF or misconfigured DNS forwarding).
    • Altering container hosts /etc/hosts or DNS configuration.
    • Exploiting weak or unauthenticated custom DNS zones used for ECS service discovery.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Redirection: ECS tasks connect to attacker-controlled services, leaking credentials or data.
  • Data Exfiltration & Manipulation: Sensitive payloads intended for real backends are intercepted or altered.
  • Operational Disruption: Tasks fail health checks or crash when they cant reach legitimate services.
  • Lateral Movement: Redirected service calls provide a foothold to pivot deeper into your VPC.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Resolver Cache Poisoning: An attacker exploits an SSRF vulnerability in a container to poison the VPCs DNS cache, mapping db.internal to their server. Tasks then send credentials and queries to the rogue host.
  2. Hosts File Tamper: A compromised container image includes a malicious entry in /etc/hosts for the ECS service DNS name, diverting all inter-task API calls to a backdoor listener.
  3. Custom DNS Zone Exploit: A custom Route 53 private zone used for service discovery has weak IAM controls; an attacker adds a record pointing your services CNAME to an external IP, intercepting traffic from new task launches.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Vulnerable container images deployed on cluster
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Deploying container images with known vulnerabilities (unpatched OS packages, outdated libraries, or insecure configurations) exposes your ECS tasks to exploitation by attackers.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated vulnerability scanners, and supply-chain adversaries
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Pulling in images with unpatched CVEs from public registries
    • Reusing deprecated or unsupported base images
    • Injecting malicious code into images via compromised CI/CD pipelines

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Exploitable flaws allow attackers to run arbitrary code in your cluster
  • Container Breakouts: Privilege-escalation bugs enable access to the ECS host or other tasks
  • Data Theft & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by the container can be exfiltrated or modified
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised containers serve as beachheads for attacking other services

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: An attacker exploits a known RCE in an outdated web-server image to inject backdoors into your application.
  2. Cryptojacking: A malicious image layer installs crypto-miners on container hosts, consuming CPU and racking up costs.
  3. Supply-Chain Attack: A compromised build pipeline injects a trojan into your image; once deployed, it harvests AWS credentials via the task metadata endpoint.

component.name: Source Cluster Snapshot
component.desc: Snapshot of the source cluster stored in Amazon S3.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-347
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-347: Improper Verification of Cryptographic Signature The product does not verify, or incorrectly verifies, the cryptographic signature for data.

countermeasure.name: Apply Vault Access Policies to enforce granular permissions on Glacier vaults
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure secure access to AWS S3 Glacier vaults, apply Vault Access Policies that specify which users or roles can perform specific actions, such as read or write operations. This helps enforce the principle of least privilege and prevents unauthorized access.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Create an Access Policy: Define a JSON policy outlining permitted actions and authorized IAM users or roles.
  2. Attach the Policy: Use the AWS Console or CLI to apply the policy to the Glacier vault.
  3. Test and Monitor: Verify the policy works as intended and use AWS CloudTrail to monitor access.
  4. Review Regularly: Update policies as needed to align with changing security requirements.

countermeasure.name: Implement data retrieval policies to manage S3 Glacier retrieval costs
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively manage costs and optimize retrieval performance in AWS S3 Glacier, implement data retrieval policies. These policies control the amount of data that can be retrieved per hour and set retrieval priorities, such as Standard, Bulk, or Expedited, ensuring cost-effective data access.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Define a Retrieval Policy: Specify limits on data retrieval rates and set retrieval priorities based on business needs.
  2. Apply the Policy: Use the AWS Management Console or CLI to configure the retrieval policy on the S3 Glacier vault.
  3. Monitor Usage: Regularly review retrieval logs to ensure the policy is effective and adjust as needed to align with cost management goals.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Leverage S3 Glacier Select for in-place data querying
countermeasure.desc:
Use S3 Glacier Select to execute SQL queries directly on data stored in AWS S3 Glacier without fully retrieving it. This approach minimizes the costs and time associated with processing large, infrequently accessed datasets by retrieving only the necessary data for analysis.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Prepare SQL Queries: Write SQL queries that specify the data you need directly from the S3 Glacier storage.
  2. Use Glacier Select: Utilize the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDKs to run these queries against the stored data in Glacier.
  3. Review Costs and Performance: Monitor the costs and performance benefits from using Glacier Select and adjust query parameters as needed to optimize cost savings.

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Glacier Deep Archive for long-term, infrequent access storage
countermeasure.desc:
For data that requires long-term retention but is rarely accessed, utilize AWS S3 Glacier Deep Archive. This storage class provides a cost-effective solution with retrieval times of up to 12 hours, making it ideal for compliance and archival data that does not need immediate access.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Select Glacier Deep Archive: Choose the Glacier Deep Archive storage class when creating or updating S3 bucket policies for long-term data storage.
  2. Configure Data Lifecycle Policies: Set up lifecycle policies to automatically transition infrequently accessed data to Glacier Deep Archive after a specified period.
  3. Plan for Retrieval Times: Be aware of the longer retrieval times (up to 12 hours) and plan access requirements accordingly.

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Glacier Vault Lock to enforce immutability for compliance
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure regulatory compliance and protect data integrity, configure S3 Glacier Vault Lock on your AWS S3 Glacier vaults. Vault Lock allows you to create a lockable policy that enforces a Write Once, Read Many (WORM) model. Once the Vault Lock policy is set and locked, it becomes immutable, meaning no user, including those with administrative privileges, can modify or delete data. This is crucial for meeting regulatory requirements that mandate the preservation of records in their original state.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Create a Vault Lock Policy: Navigate to the AWS Management Console, open the S3 Glacier service, and select the vault for which you want to apply the policy.
  2. Define the WORM Policy: Write a Vault Lock policy specifying the compliance rules, such as retention periods and actions that are restricted (e.g., delete or overwrite).
  3. Initiate the Vault Lock Process: Apply the policy to the vault and initiate the Vault Lock. The policy enters a 'pending' state during which you can test it by attempting operations that would be restricted by the policy.
  4. Lock the Policy: After testing, finalize the policy to lock it. Once locked, the policy becomes immutable, ensuring data cannot be altered or deleted.
  5. Monitor Compliance: Regularly audit the vault to ensure no unauthorized changes have been made and that the data complies with your regulatory and retention requirements.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: High costs of long-term storage
threat.desc:
High Costs of Long-Term Storage occur when data stored in AWS S3 Glacier, particularly in higher-cost storage classes like Glacier Deep Archive, accumulates over time, leading to increased expenses. Without proper lifecycle management, data that remains stored without being accessed can result in unnecessarily high storage costs.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Internal users, administrators, or systems lacking proper storage policies.
  • Attack Vectors: Retaining data in expensive storage classes without regular reviews or applying lifecycle policies to move infrequently accessed data to cheaper storage.

Impacts:

  • Financial Impact: Increased storage costs, affecting budget allocations and potentially leading to wasteful spending.
  • Operational Impact: Misallocation of resources that could otherwise be optimized for cost-efficiency.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An organization fails to implement lifecycle policies, leaving large amounts of old data in Glacier Deep Archive, resulting in substantial monthly charges.
  2. A data lake is set to store all data in S3 Glacier without differentiating between active and inactive datasets, leading to high costs for infrequently accessed data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1671 - Cloud Application Integration

threat.name: Inefficient data processing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Inefficient Data Processing refers to the costly and time-consuming retrieval of large datasets from AWS S3 Glacier for analysis. Glacier is optimized for long-term archival storage, not frequent or real-time data processing, making full data retrieval operations potentially inefficient and expensive.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Data analysts, automated workflows, or applications not optimized for Glacier's retrieval constraints.
  • Attack Vectors: Full data retrievals for analysis, lack of using tools like S3 Glacier Select for targeted queries, or improper configuration of data processing tasks.

Impacts:

  • Financial Impact: Increased retrieval costs and processing overhead.
  • Operational Impact: Delays in data processing, increased workload on systems and personnel.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. A data scientist retrieves a complete dataset from S3 Glacier for analysis instead of using selective queries, resulting in unnecessary costs and time delays.
  2. Automated ETL processes are set up to retrieve and process entire data sets regularly, without consideration of the infrequent access pattern, leading to inefficiencies and higher expenses.

threat.name: Excessive data retrieval costs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Excessive Data Retrieval Costs occur when large volumes of data are retrieved from AWS S3 Glacier, leading to unexpected high charges. S3 Glacier is intended for infrequent access, and costs can escalate quickly with frequent or high-speed retrievals.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Internal users, misconfigured systems, malicious insiders, or external attackers with access to AWS credentials.
  • Attack Vectors: Automated retrieval processes, bulk or expedited data requests, compromised credentials.

Impacts:

  • Financial Impact: High costs affecting budget and operations.
  • Operational Impact: Resource reallocation, project delays.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An employee unintentionally triggers a bulk data retrieval, causing unexpected charges.
  2. A compromised account is used to request large amounts of data, leading to financial loss and potential data breaches.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1530 - Data from Cloud Storage

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Glacier vaults
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Unauthorized Access to Glacier Vaults occurs when unauthorized users gain access to AWS S3 Glacier vaults, potentially leading to data breaches, data manipulation, or loss. Glacier vaults are intended to store highly sensitive or critical archival data, and inadequate access controls can result in unauthorized actions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers with stolen credentials, or misconfigured user permissions.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak access controls, using compromised AWS credentials, or leveraging overly permissive vault access policies to gain unauthorized access to Glacier vaults.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Unauthorized users may exfiltrate sensitive data.
  • Data Loss or Manipulation: Critical data may be deleted or altered, impacting business continuity and compliance.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker gains access to AWS credentials with permissions to a Glacier vault and deletes critical archival data, causing irreparable loss.
  2. A misconfigured vault access policy allows an unauthorized internal user to access and manipulate sensitive compliance data, leading to regulatory violations.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Data integrity and compliance violations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Data Integrity and Compliance Violations occur when data stored in AWS S3 Glacier is tampered with, deleted, or not stored in a manner compliant with regulatory requirements. Glacier is often used for long-term storage of critical data, such as financial records or legal documents, where maintaining data integrity and adhering to compliance standards are crucial.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, or misconfigured systems.
  • Attack Vectors: Unauthorized modifications or deletions due to inadequate access controls, lack of immutable storage configurations (like WORM policies), or errors in data handling processes.

Impacts:

  • Compliance Impact: Breaches in regulatory requirements can result in fines, legal action, and loss of certifications.
  • Operational Impact: Corrupted or lost data can affect business continuity, damage reputation, and hinder decision-making processes.
  • Financial Impact: Costs associated with data recovery, legal fines, and potential loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An internal employee with excessive permissions accidentally deletes or alters archived financial records, resulting in non-compliance with financial reporting regulations.
  2. An external attacker gains unauthorized access to a Glacier vault and deletes sensitive legal documents stored for compliance purposes, causing the organization to fail audits and face regulatory penalties.
  3. A misconfigured automated script overwrites critical archival data in Glacier, resulting in permanent data loss and failure to meet data retention requirements.

component.name: Target Cluster
component.desc: The destination Amazon OpenSearch or Elasticsearch cluster.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-309
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-309: Use of Password System for Primary Authentication The use of password systems as the primary means of authentication may be subject to several flaws or shortcomings, each reducing the effectiveness of the mechanism.

weakness.name: CWE-511
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-511: Logic/Time Bomb The product contains code that is designed to disrupt the legitimate operation of the product (or its environment) when a certain time passes, or when a certain logical condition is met. When the time bomb or logic bomb is detonated, it may perform a denial of service such as crashing the system, deleting critical data, or degrading system response time. This bomb might be placed within either a replicating or non-replicating Trojan horse.

weakness.name: CWE-710
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-710: Improper Adherence to Coding Standards The product does not follow certain coding rules for development, which can lead to resultant weaknesses or increase the severity of the associated vulnerabilities.

weakness.name: CWE-829
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-829: Inclusion of Functionality from Untrusted Control Sphere The product imports, requires, or includes executable functionality (such as a library) from a source that is outside of the intended control sphere.

countermeasure.name: Configure CPU and memory limits and set sensible auto scaling policies
countermeasure.desc:
All compute resources that sit in public subnets and receive traffic through an Internet Gateway (IGW) EC2 instances, container tasks, or NAT instances must be protected against resource exhaustion and denial-of-service conditions by:

  1. Defining hard resource limits
    • EC2/ASG: choose an instance family and size that leaves head-room at peak load; tag the launch template with MaxCPU and MaxMemory targets (for example, 70 % CPU, 80 % RAM).
    • ECS/Fargate: declare cpu and memory hard limits in the task definition so a runaway container is killed before it starves neighbours.
    • Lambda & API Gateway: set concurrency limits per account or function to cap burst traffic.
  2. Instrumenting CloudWatch metrics
    • Use built-in CPUUtilization and the mem_used_percent custom metric (CloudWatch Agent) to monitor utilisation.
    • Create alarms that fire at 60 %70 % of capacity; wire them to Auto Scaling policies.
  3. Implementing sensible Auto Scaling
    • Target-tracking policy: keep CPU at 50 % for web fleets or request count per target for ALBs (e.g., 2 000 req/min/instance).
    • Set min and max instance counts so scale-in never drops below an AZ-redundant baseline and scale-out stops before cost or quota limits are hit.
    • For Spot or mixed-fleet groups, define an on-demand base to survive Spot interrupts.
  4. Testing & tuning
    • Run monthly load tests (Distributed Load Testing on AWS or Locust) that push traffic to 2 historical peak; confirm scaling adds capacity before CPU or memory breaches.
    • Review scaling activity logs; adjust cooldowns and target values to avoid thrash.

By capping resource usage and letting Auto Scaling add or remove capacity automatically, you prevent public-facing workloads from failing under load spikes that enter via the IGW, while keeping costs and quotas predictable.

References

  • EC2 Auto Scaling target-tracking policies
  • Amazon ECS task CPU and memory settings

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1018 - User Account Management

countermeasure.name: Enable automated image scanning and enforce image provenance
countermeasure.desc:
Any container image that will run in a subnet routed through an Internet Gateway must pass an automated vulnerability scan and come from a cryptographically trusted source before it is deployed:

  1. Automated scanning pipeline
    • Push images only to an Amazon ECR repository with image scanning on push or Amazon Inspector enhanced scanning enabled.
    • Fail the build if the scan reports critical or high CVEs that lack an approved mitigation tag.
  2. Signed provenance
    • Enable ECR image signing (SigV4 + AWS Signer) or OCI Notary v2; require every tag to have a valid signature from the CI service accounts signing profile.
    • Attach an IAM condition to the task-execution role that denies ecr:BatchGetImage when ecr:ImageHasSignature is "false".
  3. Admission control
    • In ECS, reference the image digest (@sha256:) rather than :latest tags in task definitions.
    • For EKS, install an admission controller (OPA / Kyverno) that blocks unsigned or unscanned images.
  4. Continuous verification
    • Run nightly re-scan jobs on all repositories; raise Jira/SNS alerts for new CVEs.
    • Rotate signing keys annually; store them in KMS with key policies that allow only the CI role to sign.

By combining automated CVE scanning with enforced signatures, you ensure that no unvetted or tampered image can reach compute resources exposed to the internet via the IGW.

References

  • Amazon ECR image scanning and signing
  • Amazon Inspector container vulnerability scanning

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity
SI-6 Security and Privacy Function Verification
SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

customField.value: SI-7 Software, Firmware, and Information Integrity

countermeasure.name: Enable CloudTrail, VPC flow logs, and container insights monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Collect control-plane, network, and runtime telemetry for every workload that egresses through an Internet Gateway (IGW):

  1. AWS CloudTrail who changed what
    • Enable an organization-wide, multi-Region trail that captures Management events (EC2, ECS, EKS, IAM) and delivers them to an SSE-KMSencrypted S3 bucket.
    • Stream the trail to CloudWatch Logs or Security Lake so you can create real-time alarms on RunTask, UpdateService, or ModifyVpcEndpoint operations.
  2. VPC Flow Logs who talked to whom
    • Turn on Flow Logs (version 3) for every public subnet and for the ENIs of NAT gateways, load balancers, and container tasks.
    • Send logs to CloudWatch Logs with at least 90-day retention; build metric filters for unexpected ports, denied connections, or traffic to disallowed CIDRs.
  3. Amazon CloudWatch Container Insights whats happening inside
    • For ECS/Fargate: enable Container Insights in the cluster settings or via aws ecs update-cluster-settings --settings name=containerInsights,value=enabled.
    • For EKS: deploy the CloudWatch agent Helm chart (amazon-cloudwatch-agent) with the containerInsights=true flag.
    • Collect CPU, memory, and network-I/O metrics per task/pod; create alarms when utilisation exceeds 80 % or when restarts spike.
  4. Integrate & alert
    • Pipe CloudTrail and Flow-Log findings to Security Hub; forward high-severity alerts to your on-call channel via SNS or PagerDuty.
    • Build unified CloudWatch dashboards that overlay network traffic, container resource usage, and recent configuration changes to speed incident triage.
  5. Compliance & retention
    • Store all logs for at least one year (or your regulatory window) in S3 Glacier Instant Retrieval or Deep Archive.
    • Use AWS Config rules (vpc-flow-logs-enabled, custom Container Insights checks) to ensure telemetry cant be disabled without raising a finding.

With these three data sources combined, you can answer who changed it, what traffic flowed, and how the container behavedcritical information for detection, response, and forensic analysis.

References

  • Logging and monitoring in Amazon VPC
  • Amazon CloudWatch Container Insights

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege for task execution and task roles
countermeasure.desc:
Every container running in a subnet that egresses through an Internet Gateway should assume two distinct IAM roles, each scoped to the minimum actions and resources it needs:

  1. Task-execution role (AWS-managed actions only)
    • Used by ECS/Fargate to pull the image, decrypt secrets, push logs.
    • Allow only:
      • ecr:GetAuthorizationToken, ecr:BatchGetImage, ecr:GetDownloadUrlForLayer
      • logs:CreateLogStream, logs:PutLogEvents
      • secretsmanager:GetSecretValue or ssm:GetParameters (if you mount secrets)
    • Attach the AWS-managed policy AmazonECSTaskExecutionRolePolicy as a starting point, then remove services you dont use (for example, KMS if no encrypted secrets).
  2. Task (application) role
    • Assumed by the container code itself.
    • Enumerate required AWS APIs (e.g., dynamodb:PutItem, sqs:SendMessage); scope Resource to the exact table, queue, or bucket ARN.
    • Add condition keys (dynamodb:LeadingKeys, s3:prefix, aws:SourceVpc, etc.) to stop lateral access.
  3. Hard stops with permission boundaries
    • Create an account-wide boundary that denies wildcard actions/resources (iam:*, *:*) and attach it to all task and execution roles.
    • Use an SCP to block iam:PutRolePolicy if it grants * or omits conditions.
  4. Continuous validation
    • Turn on IAM Access Analyzer: unused permissions to prune actions not called for 90 days.
    • Enable AWS Config rule ecs-task-definition-no-exec-role-with-admin-access (custom) to flag roles containing AdministratorAccess or *.
    • Fail CI/CD builds when a task definition references taskRoleArn or executionRoleArn that lacks the boundary or uses wildcard permissions.
  5. Review cadence
    • Quarterly, export CloudTrail evidence of actions used by each role; tighten policies and retire dormant roles.
    • Rotate secrets (DB creds, API keys) and ensure the new ARNs are still covered by the scoped policies.

References

  • IAM roles for Amazon ECS tasks
  • Designing least-privilege IAM policies

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1022 - Restrict File and Directory Permissions

countermeasure.name: Limit IAM permissions and use IAM conditions for task roles
countermeasure.desc:
Give each ECS (or Fargate) task a minimum-privilege IAM role and add condition keys so the permissions are honored only when the request context matches your workloads environment.

  1. Start with the narrowest allow list
    • List the exact API calls the container needs (e.g., dynamodb:PutItem, s3:GetObject, kms:Decrypt).
    • Scope Resource to concrete ARNstable, bucket prefix, secret IDnever *.
  2. Add context-based conditions
    • Network origin aws:SourceVpc, aws:SourceVpce, or aws:SourceIp ensures the call originates from the correct VPC or endpoint.
    • Calling service aws:CalledVia = ecs-tasks.amazonaws.com stops the same role being used elsewhere.
    • Data partition dynamodb:LeadingKeys or s3:prefix pins access to one tenant ID.
    • Encryption scope kms:EncryptionContext:aws:logs:arn restricts decryption to this tasks log group.
    • {
       "Effect": "Allow",
       "Action": "s3:GetObject",
       "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::media-bucket/tenantA/*",
       "Condition": {
         "StringEquals": { "aws:SourceVpce": "vpce-0abc123def456" }
       }
      }
  3. Enforce via CI/CD and guardrails
    • Fail the build if a task role policy contains Action:"*" or lacks a Condition block for network or tenant context.
    • Attach an account-wide permission boundary that denies any role granting wildcards.
    • Enable an AWS Config custom rule or Security Hub control that flags task roles missing aws:SourceVpc/aws:SourceVpce.
  4. Validate and prune
    • Turn on IAM Access Analyzer unused permissions to spot actions never called in the last 90 days; remove them.
    • Review CloudTrail logs quarterly to confirm the condition keys are actually evaluated on every call.

Condition-based least privilege ensures thateven if credentials leakcalls succeed only from the intended task in the intended VPC, sharply reducing blast radius.

References

  • IAM roles for Amazon ECS tasks
  • IAM policy elements condition keys

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

countermeasure.name: Place tasks in private subnets and restrict security groups
countermeasure.desc:
Keep container workloads off the public internet by launching every ECS / Fargate task in private subnets (no direct route to the Internet Gateway) and attaching a least-privilege security group (SG):

  1. Subnet design
    • Mark the subnet private by removing the 0.0.0.0/0 (and ::/0) route to the IGW.
    • Provide outbound access, if required, through a NAT Gateway or interface VPC endpoints (S3, DynamoDB, STS, etc.).
  2. Restrictive security group
    • Ingress: allow only the ports and protocols your service actually listens ontypically the ALB or NLB target portand reference the load balancers SG rather than broad CIDRs.
    • Egress: delete the default all-traffic rule; add specific rules for HTTPS to VPC endpoints or database SGs.
  3. IAM & task definition
    • In the task definition, set awsvpcConfiguration subnets to the private subnet IDs and securityGroups to the locked-down SG.
    • Prevent drift with an AWS Config rule or CI linter that fails if a task definition references a public subnet or a SG open to 0.0.0.0/0.
  4. Validation & monitoring
    • Use Reachability Analyzer to confirm the task ENI cannot reach the IGW directly.
    • Turn on VPC Flow Logs for the subnet; alarm on any flow where the destination is a public IP outside AWS service ranges.

Placing tasks in private subnets breaks direct inbound paths from the internet, while tight SG rules stop lateral movement and inadvertent outbound leaks.

References

  • Deploying Amazon ECS tasks on AWS Fargate in private subnets
  • Security groups for your VPC best practices

countermeasure.name: Use Route 53 private DNS and enforce TLS for service communications
countermeasure.desc:
Keep service-to-service calls inside the VPC and encrypted end-to-end:

  1. Create private hosted zones
    • In Route 53, create a private hosted zone (e.g., internal.example.com) associated with all application VPCs.
    • Add records (api.internal.example.com, db.internal.example.com, etc.) that point to the target ENIs, NLBs, or interface VPC endpointsnever public IPs.
  2. Block public resolution paths
    • Add a Resolver DNS-firewall (or outbound forwarding rule) that drops queries for the same names in public DNS, forcing workloads to use the private mapping.
    • For interface VPC endpoints, keep Private DNS enabled so SDK calls (S3, STS, KMS, etc.) automatically resolve to VPC-local IPs.
  3. Enforce TLS 1.2+ everywhere
    • Expose every internal service only on TCP 443; delete port 80 listeners or redirect them with an ALB 301 rule.
    • For NLB TLS termination or ACM certificates on ALB/API Gateway, choose an AWS security policy that requires TLS 1.2 with PFS (or TLS 1.3).
    • In container images/AMIs, set MinProtocol = TLSv1.2 in OpenSSL or JVM settings; reject plaintext fallback.
  4. Harden network paths
    • Security groups: allow outbound traffic only to port 443 on the service SG or endpoint SG; block 80/HTTP entirely.
    • Route tables: ensure subnets have routes for the private DNS targets (interface endpoints, NLB subnets) and no direct IGW path for internal traffic.
  5. Monitor & validate
    • Enable Route 53 Resolver Query Logging; alarm on queries for private names that resolve to public IPs.
    • Use VPC Flow Logs to detect port 80 or non-TLS port usage; create CloudWatch metric filters that trigger when they appear.

Implementing private DNS plus mandatory TLS keeps all east-west traffic on the AWS backbone, removes plaintext exposure, and simplifies firewall and compliance audits.

References

  • Route 53 private hosted zones

ID.SC-2: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process
PR.IP-2: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented
SA-15 Development Process, Standards, and Tools

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource exhaustion leading to denial of service
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Resource exhaustion in an ECS cluster occurs when CPU, memory, or network capacity is consumed by benign spikes or malicious workloads, preventing legitimate tasks from running and causing service outages.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious containers, compromised tasks, rogue admins or CI/CD pipelines.
  • Vectors:
    • Deploying tasks with unbounded resource requests (e.g. high CPU/memory).
    • Flooding the cluster with excessive task launch requests.
    • Memory leaks or runaway processes within containers.

Impacts

  • Task Failures: New and running services crash or are throttled.
  • Service Unavailability: APIs, jobs, and background processors become unresponsive.
  • Escalating Costs: Over-provisioned autoscaling spins up extra instances with no real demand.
  • Operational Overhead: Manual intervention needed to drain or rebalance the cluster.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Malicious Task Flood: An attacker with deploy rights launches hundreds of high-memory tasks, filling all container instances and blocking legitimate services.
  2. Runaway Process: A buggy microservice enters a tight loop consuming 100% CPU on its host; autoscaling cant keep up, and subsequent tasks remain pending.
  3. CI/CD Storm: A misconfigured pipeline repeatedly redeploys containers without resource limits, triggering rapid scale-outs and eventual cluster exhaustion.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Task execution role with excessive IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When an ECS task execution role is granted broad or wildcard IAM privileges, tasks gain more AWS access than requiredviolating least-privilege principles and enabling misuse.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious container code, compromised tasks, or insider threats.
  • Vectors:
    • Task roles with policies like iam:* or * on all resources.
    • Sharing execution roles across multiple services.
    • Inadequate policy scoping in Terraform/CloudFormation.

Impacts

  • Privilege Escalation: Tasks can call sensitive APIscreating or deleting IAM users, roles, or keys.
  • Data Breach & Tampering: Unauthorized read/write of S3 buckets, secrets, or databases.
  • Lateral Movement: Pivoting to other AWS services or regions.
  • Operational Disruption: Unintended resource creation or deletion.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A container uses its over-permissive role to call iam:CreateUser and issues new admin credentials.
  2. A compromised task reads secretsmanager:GetSecretValue, harvesting database passwords.
  3. A CI/CD pipeline with a wildcard execution role deploys tasks that spin up costly EC2 instances.

threat.name: Compromised container abusing AWS APIs
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A breached container with AWS credentials (via task roles or env vars) can call AWS APIs to manipulate resources and move laterally in your account.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Supply-chain compromises, insiders, or remote code exploits
  • Vectors: Stealing IAM role tokens from the metadata endpoint, extracting hard-coded keys, abusing over-permissive task-role policies

Impacts

  • Privilege escalation and lateral movement
  • Data exfiltration from S3, RDS, etc.
  • Resource destruction or unauthorized creation
  • Persistent backdoors via new IAM principals

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Exploited app vulnerability reads task metadata, grabs role credentials, and deletes CloudFormation stacks.
  2. Malicious image embeds AWS keys, used to spin up costly EC2 instances.
  3. Over-privileged role abused to create an admin IAM user for ongoing access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Network exposure of container instances
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Network exposure of container instances occurs when ECS tasks or underlying EC2 instances are placed in subnets or security groups that allow unintended inbound or outbound trafficmaking them directly reachable from the Internet or other untrusted networks.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, opportunistic scanners, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Assigning container instances to public subnets without NAT or firewall controls.
    • Security groups permitting broad CIDRs (e.g. 0.0.0.0/0) on management ports (SSH, RDP) or application ports.
    • Misconfigured load-balancer target groups forwarding traffic to private instances.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can probe and exploit services running in containers.
  • Data Breach & Tampering: Exposed management interfaces allow configuration changes or credential theft.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious traffic or exploits lead to container crashes and downtime.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised instances become beachheads for attacking other resources in the VPC.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open SSH Port: A container instances SG allows SSH from anywhere; an attacker brute-forces the host and moves laterally into other ECS services.
  2. Public App Endpoint: A web service is deployed in a public subnet without WAF protection; vulnerability scanners find and exploit a known flaw, injecting malicious code.
  3. Load-Balancer Misroute: An internal-only API is mistakenly registered with a public ALB; its endpoints become reachable and are used to exfiltrate sensitive data.

threat.name: Lack of visibility into cluster and task activity
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Without centralized logging or monitoring of ECS clusters and tasks, malicious or misconfigured activitysuch as unauthorized deployments, resource abuse, or lateral movementoccurs undetected.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised task containers, misconfigured CI/CD pipelines
  • Vectors:
    • No CloudWatch Logs or Container Insights enabled for task logs and metrics
    • Absence of CloudTrail events for RunTask, StopTask, or RegisterTaskDefinition
    • Missing EventBridge rules to capture ECS state changes

Impacts

  • Undetected Compromise: Rogue containers or altered task definitions run unnoticed
  • Delayed Response: Security incidents arent flagged, extending attacker dwell time
  • Compliance Gaps: Failure to meet audit-logging requirements (e.g., PCI DSS, SOC 2)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. A rogue image is deployed via an unchecked pipeline; without audit logs, the change isnt traced.
  2. A compromised task spins up crypto-mining containers; absent metrics alerts, resource exhaustion goes unremedied.
  3. An attacker uses the ECS API to stop security-critical tasks; no EventBridge rule exists to notify on task shutdown.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1613 - Container and Resource Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: DNS spoofing in service discovery
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
DNS spoofing in service discovery occurs when an attacker injects false DNS entrieseither via compromised DNS servers, poisoned caches, or manipulated /etc/hostscausing ECS tasks to resolve service names (e.g. your internal API or database endpoint) to malicious addresses.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised DNS resolvers, or on-host attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Poisoning the VPCs DNS resolver cache (e.g. via SSRF or misconfigured DNS forwarding).
    • Altering container hosts /etc/hosts or DNS configuration.
    • Exploiting weak or unauthenticated custom DNS zones used for ECS service discovery.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Redirection: ECS tasks connect to attacker-controlled services, leaking credentials or data.
  • Data Exfiltration & Manipulation: Sensitive payloads intended for real backends are intercepted or altered.
  • Operational Disruption: Tasks fail health checks or crash when they cant reach legitimate services.
  • Lateral Movement: Redirected service calls provide a foothold to pivot deeper into your VPC.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Resolver Cache Poisoning: An attacker exploits an SSRF vulnerability in a container to poison the VPCs DNS cache, mapping db.internal to their server. Tasks then send credentials and queries to the rogue host.
  2. Hosts File Tamper: A compromised container image includes a malicious entry in /etc/hosts for the ECS service DNS name, diverting all inter-task API calls to a backdoor listener.
  3. Custom DNS Zone Exploit: A custom Route 53 private zone used for service discovery has weak IAM controls; an attacker adds a record pointing your services CNAME to an external IP, intercepting traffic from new task launches.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Vulnerable container images deployed on cluster
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Deploying container images with known vulnerabilities (unpatched OS packages, outdated libraries, or insecure configurations) exposes your ECS tasks to exploitation by attackers.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated vulnerability scanners, and supply-chain adversaries
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Pulling in images with unpatched CVEs from public registries
    • Reusing deprecated or unsupported base images
    • Injecting malicious code into images via compromised CI/CD pipelines

Impacts

  • Remote Code Execution: Exploitable flaws allow attackers to run arbitrary code in your cluster
  • Container Breakouts: Privilege-escalation bugs enable access to the ECS host or other tasks
  • Data Theft & Tampering: Sensitive data processed by the container can be exfiltrated or modified
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised containers serve as beachheads for attacking other services

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. CVE Exploit: An attacker exploits a known RCE in an outdated web-server image to inject backdoors into your application.
  2. Cryptojacking: A malicious image layer installs crypto-miners on container hosts, consuming CPU and racking up costs.
  3. Supply-Chain Attack: A compromised build pipeline injects a trojan into your image; once deployed, it harvests AWS credentials via the task metadata endpoint.
